title: south ayrshire council completes roll
story: NewsSouth Ayrshire Council completes roll-out of new rubbish bin schemeThe councils scheme to roll-out a new recycling service is finally complete.ShareByStephen Houston:,  APR NewsThe new bins are mounting up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe campaign to introduce a new recycling service in South Ayrshire has been completed after a  month roll-out. People in , properties are now being encouraged to help increase the quality of the recycling collected while also increasing the amount of materials recycled. Two new smaller bins have been introduced for ‘Paper, Card and Cardboard’, and ‘Glass Bottles and Jars’, while existing blue bins are being used for ‘Metals, Plastics and Cartons’. Uplt of the ‘Non-recyclable’ green bin has changed, with collections every three weeks. The final stage of the programme has seen the service introduced to , properties in Monkton, Sundrum, St Quivox and parts of Ayr and the last remaining rural properties. The service went live in these areas on Monday, April . Large quantities of recyclable materials and food waste are currently left in general waste bins and end up in landfill sites.  Council figures suggest that % of waste left in green bins is food % is paper, card and cardboard and % is metal, plastic and cartons – all of which can be recycled. Every year more than , tonnes of household waste is sent to landfill, leading to increased costs to the public expense. Councillor Ian Cochrane, South Ayrshire Council’s Portfolio Holder for Environment, “With the final pieces of the jigsaw now in place, the whole of South Ayrshire is now using the new service, helping us to meet ambitious national recycling targets. “We’ve taken a flexible approach with a mix of kerbside and communal services available. “I appreciate the change is a sht in the way people have to recycle but we know from our rounds that the vast majority of people have switched.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilEnvironmentAyr NewsAyr

title: south ayrshire council launch public
story: NewsSouth Ayrshire Council launch public consultation on new parking charges in Ayr, Troon and PrestwickA consultation is being held on the proposals to charge at a range of new sites, including the busy Tams Brig car park.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  APR NewsCouncil chiefs could charge a pretty penny to park at Tams Brig "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCar park charges branded a “scandalous tax on drivers” are being put to the public. Moves to implement fees across a raft of new sites face a four-week trial by consultation. Feedback will decide the fate of controversial proposals – which include multiple car parks in Ayr, Troon and Prestwick. And we can reveal a new car park – never identied in the council’s original plans last year – has made the cut at the eleventh hour. Bosses want to charge £ a day for drivers to use the packed New Road car park at Tam’s Brig. Other sites include Blackburn Drive’s beach car park in Ayr and Bellevue Road in Prestwick. While Troon will be targeted at Titchfield Road, South Beach Roadand South Beach Esplanade. Meanwhile public car parks in Maybole and Girvan escape scot free. Proposed charges of p per half hour are being made by the Ayrshire Road Alliance, carrying out the move on behalf of South Ayrshire Council. But the move to add Tam’s Brig to the list, where drivers will be charged £ per day, has sparked fury. Council opposition leader, Martin Dowey, said: “The biggest complaint about our towns – particularly Ayr – is the lack of free parking provision. As a council we need to be asking ourselves whether we are open for business or are we determined to keep driving people away for good ”  Meanwhile, councillors in Prestwick insist the move to charge at the giant Bellevue Road site near the Main Street could cause chaos. Tory Hugh Hunter said: “It’s madness and nothing short of a scandalous tax on drivers and low paid workers. This sends a terrible message to the people who work in our Main Street and who will now, inevitably, be displaced into side streets looking for free space. “It will lead to untold problems.” Council chiefs insist the public has a window in which to voice its opinion, with consultation ending on May . A spokesman said: “The statutory timescales for the TROprocess include a period of public consultation, which will provide the opportunity for local people to have their say on the proposed introduction of charges. “The consultation feedback and the TROs will be considered by the council’s Regulatory Panel in June. “Objectors must state their reasons in writing to the Head of Roads of the Ayrshire Roads Alliance.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilTaxesTroonPrestwickGirvanAyr NewsAyr

title: call-to-rename-a72-blackspot-after-campaigner-mollie
story: A CALL has been made to rename a notorious stretch of road in memory of the woman who spent decades fighting for safety measures at the accident blackspot.Over the past two weeks, tributes have been flooding in to remember Mollie McIntosh, who died at the age of .And, as Walkerburnrsquos oldest resident was this week laid to rest, former council convenor Graham Garvie suggested renaming Dirtpot Corner after the community stalwart.Mr Garvie, who served Tweeddale as a councillor from  until , told us: ldquoOne of main issues Mollie raised over the years was road safety.ldquoShe told me that proposals for road improvements to Dirtpot Corner were first considered by Peeblesshire County Council in .ldquoShe campaigned for many years to improve the road.ldquoShe was truly delighted that Scottish Borders Council at long last made it happen. I think now that work has eventually started at Dirtpot Corner, it would be nice to name it after her. She did so much good work in the community.The -month programme of improvement works began at the bottleneck on the A between Peebles and Innerleithen in August of last year.Above: Dirtpot CornerAs well as widening the carriageway, the pound. million scheme will also feature an improved road surface and the addition of modern road safety fencing as well as a parapet.Mr Garvie added: ldquoMollie was such a public orientated person and very motivated to get things done.ldquoDirtpot Corner is a horrible name and I hope we can somehow get it renamed lsquoMolliersquos Cornerrsquo once the work is all finished.ldquoAt one time it was very common to name streets and roads after people ndash for example we have Pennelrsquos Close and Veitchrsquos Corner in Peebles. But we donrsquot see that happen so often now.ldquoIt is only a suggestion, but I hope we could make it happen.ldquoMollie would be the last person to seek any kind of recognition but wouldnrsquot it be a lovely gesture to mark her extraordinary and exemplary record of public service.ldquoA lasting tribute to a truly remarkable lady.Council leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoI think it is a lovely idea and we should certainly be looking at ways to remember Mollie in the community. We, as a council, will look at ways of doing that.A remembrance service for Mollie took place at Innerleithen Parish Church yesterday.It was attended by family, close friends and politicians as the community paid its respects.

title: borders-msp-secures-cross-party-support-for-assisted-dying-debate
story: LOCAL MSP Michelle Ballantyne is hoping that cross-party support for the concept of assisted dying will lead to a Parliamentary debate around changing legislation.Mrs Ballantyne submitted a motion to MSPs in Parliament noting that there is ldquostrong public support within the South Scotland region and across Scotland for changing the current laws to allow people to choose the manner of their own death.The MSPrsquos motion has received cross-party support from multiple SNP politicians, as well as members of the Labour Party and the Liberal Democrats.Currently, there is no law that specically bans assisted dying in Scotland.However, those aiding friends or family members, either financially or logistically, may be prosecuted under culpable homicide laws.Mrs Ballantyne, convenor of the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Cross-Party Groupon Assisted Dying, said: ldquoHaving been a nurse for many years, I feel very strongly that you should be able to choose the manner of your own death.ldquoI have spoken to many people in the Borders regarding this, I feel as though the majority of people will agree with me about this issue, regardless of your political persuasion.ldquoYou only need to look at countries like Canada and Australia where they have effective legislation which means that legally consenting adults can have a choice about how they end their lives.ldquoIrsquom encouraged that there appears to be support for this among all parties in the Scottish Parliament. I hope to work with other MSPs in order to hopefully bring forward a change in legislation.A recent poll, commissioned by campaign group Dignity in Dying Scotland, found that  percent of Scots supported legalising assisted dying for people with terminal illnesses

title: town-centre-regeneration-funding-confirmed-for-hawick
story: HAWICK town centre is set to benefit from major investment as part of a regeneration scheme designed to enhance buildings in the historic town centre.A pound. million-pound grant has been approved by Historic Environment Scotland , a public body set up to investigate, care for and promote Scotlandrsquos historic environment.The grant has been issued under the Conservation Area Regeneration Scheme , a regeneration initiative designed to direct funding to town centres across Scotland which would benefit from heritage-led redevelopment.In their application for the grant SBC highlighted the reduced footfall in Hawick town centre, amid wider socioeconomic decline, and pointed out the benefits that similar grants had brought in Kelso, Selkirk and Jedburgh.Scottish Borders Council has committed almost pound, to the scheme, which aims to conserve and enhance historic town centre buildings, with private sector contributions of over pound, added to the development fund.Following the announcement, The Council have said that ldquodetails of the scheme and grant funding opportunities will be developed and launched in due course.Councillor Mark Rowley, SBCrsquos Executive Member for Business and Economic Development, said: ldquoI am delighted that we have been successful in our application for funding for a Conservation Area Regeneration Scheme in Hawick and Irsquod like to commend the Hawick community for working with our officers to develop this ambitious proposal.ldquoThis project was a key component of the Hawick Action Plan that a range of partners helped to develop, and which has now helped attract over poundmillion of external funding.ldquoThis CARS project, along with other investments in the town, such as the redevelopment of the former Armstrongrsquos site, the new Galalaw business units and the Centre of Excellence in Textiles, will help provide a catalyst for wider regeneration and investment from the private sector.Jane Ryder OBE, Chair of Historic Environment Scotland, said: ldquoHES ambition is to provide more ways for people who live and work in Scotland to benefit from all of our historic environment, and our grants schemes are an important part of this.ldquoOne of the great merits of the CARS scheme is that it is locally led and allows local authorities to invest in priority properties they have identied and help communities to unlock the potential of their historic assets.

title: plans-go-in-for-24-apartments-on-st-aidans-site-in-galashiels
story: PLANS have been unveiled to build  apartments on the St Aidans Church site in Galashiels.Last week Cubby Construction submitted proposals for the affordable homes on the land at Gala Park.As previously reported, work is currently under way to pull down the church which was founded in .Andthe new housing plans are approved, it would see  apartments created in Gala Park and a further eight properties facing onto Livingstone Place and St Andrew Street.In the design statement submitted to SBC, architects Camerons, who are working on behalf of the developers, state: "The brief established by Cubby Construction Ltd is for a  affordable housing residential development containing a iety of apartment types suitable for the current affordable rental market conditions within Galashiels."The applicant has arrived at this brief as being the most appropriate form of re-use for the existing site in both terms of the physical restrictions of the site and economic viability."The B Listed church was originally named the South United Presbyterian Church and in  merged with the former Trinity Church on the High Street, when it became known as St Cuthbertrsquos.Then in , St Cuthbertrsquos was united with Ladhope Parish Church, being renamed St Aidanrsquos in .It finally closed its doors in  due to low congregational membership and high maintenance costs.Then in , Braedale Developments bought the plot and set out plans to create  flats, with planning permission granted in .But little interest was received after the market crashed.Following the dissolution of Braedale Developments, Book Developments Ltd took over the project in  and submitted a new planning application for a revised scheme of  flats, which was approved in .However those plans also didnt come to fruition after the Cumbrian firm said developing on the site would be uneconomical.And in September last year it was decided that the church should be demolished.Camerons added: "The [current] proposal is for a strong new building for both Galashiels, and Gala Park."[It will be] a building that contributes to the townscape of Galashiels in the same way the former church did, a landmark and contextual building that contributes to the community in this case, through affordable housing."

title: ministerial-visit-for-spa-hotel-and-employment-charity
story: THE Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills recently visited the Scottish Borders to engage with inspiring initiatives in the business and charity sectors.Jamie Hepburn MSP visited Stobo Castle, which recently received the Investors in Young People Platinumaward in recognition of its work in supporting the employment and training of young people.The family-owned destination spa has flourished by investing in staff training, and the   financial year saw profits break the one-million-pound barrier for the first time.The business has also taken a keen interest in the local community, including supporting several charities, working with local schools and funding road repairs.He was invited to Stobo by local MSP Christine Grahame, who was keen to highlight its work as a responsible employer and as an example of a successful Borders-based hospitality business.She said: ldquoIrsquom delighted the Minister has been able to come and see Stobo first hand, as itrsquos an excellent example of a successful business with a social conscience.ldquoThey really invest in their staff and place value on giving them proper training as evidenced by their IIYP Platinum status - many of its staff whom I met have been there for decades so that speaks for itself.ldquoHospitality is a key industry for our economy and itrsquos wonderful to see a business thrive locally.ldquoHaving said that, itrsquos not without its challenges in the current climate, and the Minister heard first hand from Stobo about its concerns, particularly around the current Brexit bourach given  of its staff are from other EU countries.The current owner of Stobo Castle, Stephen Winyard, echoed Ms Grahamersquos concerns about the uncertainty created by Brexit. He said: ldquoCloser to home, Brexit must not be allowed to damage Scotlandrsquos tourism industry.ldquoStobo currently employs  EU Nationals and has done for many years.ldquoThey are hugely valued and their contribution to our success is immeasurable.In addition to hearing about Stoborsquos approach to investment in its workforce and staff retention, Mr Hepburn visited a local charity that aims to equip young people with the requisite skills to gain employment.Works+, a Galashiels-based employability project, works with socially disadvantaged, unemployed young adults by offering ten-week programmes.The MSP spoke to young people currently attending the Works+ project to hear about the unique support package offered by the organisation and he praised the charity for ldquosupporting young people in the Borders into work.Scott Wight, Senior Operations Manager at Works+, told the Border : "We were delighted to welcome Jamie Hepburn to see first hand the kind of support we provide."Mr Hepburn was very interested to find out what impact this work has on participants and the local economy."The project was set up last year following the closure of Tomorrowrsquos People, an organisation which aimed to equip young people living in rural areas with the skills and confidence needed to enter the job market.Since its inception, Works+ has worked with over  young people, helping  percent of them secure employment or further education places.

title: selkirk-parish-church-sets-up-terracycle-boxes-for-recycling
story: The Parish Church in Selkirk has organised a recycling scheme for everyday items that cannot go in the usual blue bin.Biscuit wrappers that look like foil and empty toothpaste tubes cannot be recycled with the rest of the plastic.The new recycling scheme, in collaboration with TerraCycle, allows locals to recycle these items by handing them in at the church hall.Selkirk Parish Church has set up a TerraCycle box to collect wrappers in the church hall, and they have placed another box at Selkirk Dental Practice to recycle empty toothpaste tubes and old toothbrushes.TerraCycle is a company that reuses, upcycles and recycles waste instead of incinerating or landfilling it.

title: denholm-set-for-beaver-colony
story: DENHOLM is set to gain a Beaver Scout Colony ndash  years since the village last hosted Scouts.The Beaver Colony, set up by Hawick Scouts, will allow girls and boys aged between five-and-a-half and eight to experience outdoor activities, creative events and exploration of their local community.Hawick Group Scout Leader, Angela Cumming, believes the new Colony will help provide youngsters in Denholm with skills for le. She said: ldquoScouts believe in bringing people together to enjoy fun, friendship and adventure in a place they can belong.ldquoWersquore talking about teamwork, friendship and resilience ndash skills that have helped Scouts become everything from teachers and social workers to astronauts and Olympians.The new group will also be looking for adult volunteers and Angela believes volunteering with the Colony will bring its own benefits.ldquoBy becoming a volunteer, you will meet new people, feel part of your community and gain more confidence to try new experiences.ldquoThere is also the chance to make a valuable dference to childrenrsquos lives, get fit and have a lot of fun.The UKrsquos Chief Scout, adventurer Bear Grylls, also highlighted the many potential benefits awaiting volunteers. He said: ldquoVolunteering helps take your mind off your own worries and gives you a renewed sense of purpose and perspective.ldquoAnd theres overwhelming evidence that volunteering helps battle stress and anxiety, which so many of us can be prone to.ldquoOn top of that we learn new skills and interests that we can take into the workplace.A Beaver Scout information and enrolment evening will take place at pm on April  at Denholm Village Hall.Parents are invited to come along and find out more about the new Colony, as are adults and young people interested in helping to deliver activities through volunteering.

title: a-fruitful-donation-for-peebles-charity-shop
story: YOUNGSTERS from Tweeddale have raised almost pound for the Cancer Research shop in Peebles.Ruby Taylor, eight, and Taylor McDonald, , from Stobo, raised the cash through performing dance routines and selling apples to the community.And the pair recently visited the charityrsquos outlet in the High Street to hand over their pound takings.Dawn Rodger, who is manager of the shop, said: ldquoThe girls had heard their mothers talking about two friends who worked at Stobo Castle.ldquoOne of them had just lost her fight to cancer and the other had been diagnosed as terminally ill and has now sadly passed away.ldquoThe girls were saddened by this news and wanted to do something positive.ldquoThrough the school holidays the girls put on shows, dance recitals and did home baking.ldquoThey managed to make approximately pound at this point and decided to raise pound.ldquoRuby and Taylor put their heads together thinking of ideas to raise more money.That was when the girls decided to pick apples from Rubyrsquos familyrsquos apple tree.Dawn added: ldquoThey sold them for pound per bag and made a notice for why they were raising this money.ldquoThey took the fruit to the staff of Stobo Castle who gave generously.ldquoRubyrsquos sister Orla, six, and Taylorrsquos brother Murray, eight, also donated their pocket money to the cause.ldquoI think they are inspiring and we would like to say a big thank you to the enterprising youngsters.

title: moy-mackay-gallery-hosts-exciting-new-exhibition
story: AN ART Gallery in Peebles is hosting an exciting new exhibition showcasing Moy Mackayrsquos latest work and a selection of thought-provoking pieces by established visiting artists.The exhibition, hosted at the Moy Mackay Gallery, features Moyrsquos renowned textured landscapes alongside a iety of exciting works.Visitors can see new work by Roseanne Barr, where not the landscape itself but memory of it afterwards is the key concept.Barrrsquos work aims to explore and capture the mood, emotion and colours of the place filtered ldquothrough the sands of lapsed time.Her distinctive abstract style is inspired by her direct experience of the North West seaboard of Scotland and of Orkney - areas that she has known since childhood.In  Rosanne was shortlisted for the Barclays TSB Jolomo Award and her work has been selected for the Annual Exhibitions of the Royal Glasgow Institute of The Fine Arts and Paisley Art Institute.The work of Sonia Barton, characterised by the adding and removing of layers of texture, also features in the new exhibition.She describes her work as being ldquoinspired by aged and worn surfaces found in the natural and urban environments and her work with texture evokes ldquoa feeling of time and ebb and flow.The portraiture of Basia Roszak, whose work currently appears in collections across the globe from the USA to Japan, will provide visitors with another perspective on everyday le.Her portraits depict ordinary scenes in an extraordinary way and have been described as ldquovisionary, fresh, and powerfully evocative.The exhibition, which also features work by Sally Anne Fitter, Amanda Phillips, Jen Collee and Peter Jones, is running until May .

title: selkirks-lochcarron-unveils-solheim-cup-tartan
story: LOCHCARRON in Selkirk recently welcomed special guests to launch its new Solheim Cup tartan in celebration of the trophyrsquosto Scotland.European Solheim Cup captain Catriona Matthew and minister for public health, sport and wellbeing Joe FitzPatrick unveiled the special tartan during a visit last week.VisitScotland commissioned the creation of the pattern to honour the womens events long awaitedto Gleneagles in September.And Solheim Cup stalwart Catriona and Mr FitzPatrick were able to tour the factory of Lochcarron before the unveiling ceremony.Mr FitzPatrick said: ldquoIrsquom delighted to be able to unveil the official Solheim Cup tartan created by Lochcarron of Scotland, a globally renowned company based in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThe  Solheim Cup will deliver a multitude of benefits to Scotland including promoting equality across sport and society, showcasing Scotland to the world and inspiring the next generation of young male and female golfers.ldquoTartan and golf are two of Scotlandrsquos most famous exports, so it makes sense to combine them to commemorate the  Solheim Cup.Catriona, who will captain the European side at Gleneagles after nine playing appearances, added: ldquoItrsquos exciting to see the official Solheim Cup tartan and a reminder that the first tee shots will be hit at Gleneagles in a little more than five monthsrsquo time. I think the tartan looks fantastic and I love that it represents the colours of the European, US and Scottish flags.ldquoThe Solheim Cup is always hugely competitive but played in great spirit between the two teams and I think the tartan represents that perfectly.ldquoIrsquom looking forward to as much home support as possible lining the fairways at Gleneagles to cheer on the European players and I hope we can win the trophy back from what we know will be a very strong American team.Following the creation of the design, it is planned that the tartan will be included in the official merchandise and it may even feature in some of the team unorm during the competition itself.Dawn Robson-Bell, Managing Director of Lochcarron of Scotland, said: ldquoWe were thrilled to be asked by VisitScotland to create a tartan to commemorate the  Solheim Cup.ldquoTartan is historically a terric way of promoting a unity and togetherness by incorporating colours from dferent families and clans therefore it is a perfect way to commemorate this match between two teams from Europe and the US.ldquoWe look forward to seeing the tartan in the official stores during the  Solheim Cup and we hope fans on both sides will like the design.

title: selkirk-recycling-initiative-takes-the-biscuit
story: BISCUIT snackers and teeth cleaners in Selkirk are being encouraged to help the planet with some added recycling.Almost all cake bar, biscuit and cracker wrappers cant currently be put in Scottish Borders Councils blue recycling bins.And normally end up in landfill.But a new initiative at Selkirk Parish Church is hoping to reverse the trend.Anne Bethune is one of the organisers. She told us: "Even though they look like foil you canrsquot put biscuit wrappers in the blue bin."But we have now placed a TerraCycle box in Selkirk Parish Church hall for anyone to use."You can now collect biscuit, cracker and cake bar wrappers and recycle them with Terracycle."Anyone can collect the wrappers at home and take them to the church hall next time they are passing."Alternatively give them to a church member or someone who goes to pilates, zumba or new age curling in the church hall."TerraCycle collects all sorts of hard-to-recycle items which they are able to recycle into other products - so much better than sending more to landfill."A secondary TerraCycle box has also been placed with Selkirk Dental Practice for the collection of empty toothpaste tubes and old toothbrushes.

title: msp-urges-eu-citizens-to-stay-in-the-borders
story: A LOCAL MSP has made an impassioned plea to EU citizens living in the Borders, urging them remain in the region amid ongoing Brexit uncertainty.Christine Grahame, MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, has previously written to EU citizens in the area following a successful campaign to push the UK government to scrap the pound ldquosettled status fee.Ms Graham has now sought to reassure EU nationals that the Borders will remain a welcoming home. She said: ldquoIt is important to make clear that EU citizens will always remain welcome in the Borders, and I will continue to do all I can to help people stay in Scotland.ldquoItrsquos wrong for the UK government to oblige EU citizens who have built their lives in Scotland, and who contribute massively to our economy and communities, to apply for the continued right to remain in their own homes.ldquoIrsquod like to urge anyone who has issues or concerns they would like to discuss with me to please get in touch.Ms Grahamersquos stance comes after Nicola Sturgeon last week told EU citizens she would do everything she could to convince them that they are valued by Scotland.The First Minister said: ldquoIt is vital for our communities and our economy that EU nationals know they are welcome and will be supported to stay in Scotland.ldquoYou are welcome here, you contribute to this countryrsquos ersity and richness and we will do everything we can to help you to stay.

title: charity-report-highlights-debt-issues-in-borders
story: A REPORT produced by a Scottish debt charity has highlighted the extent of the debt burden in Scottish Borders constituencies.In its report Scotland in the Red, StepChange Debt Charity Scotland outlines the financial situation of Borderers who have sought their assistance with managing debts.The report draws on data from telephone debt advice sessions with clients of the charity.Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire residents utilising the charityrsquos services had an average unsecured debt balance, whereby the debt is not secured against an underlying asset, of pound,.The average Council Tax arrears for clients in the constituency was pound,, up from pound in .Clients in the Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale constituency had an average unsecured debt balance of pound, and average Council Tax arrears of pound, down from pound, in .StepChange Debt Charity Scotland provides advice to help people repay debts and campaigns for changes to public policy that will prevent problem debt and improve the situation of those affected.The charity was contacted by over , seeking help with their debts last year.The Head of StepChange Debt Charity Scotland, Sharon Bell, is particularly troubled by mounting Council Tax debts. She said: ldquoI am increasingly alarmed by the increases in the proportion of our clients who are struggling with household bills, particularly Council Tax.ldquoOur research shows that our clients in Scotland are signicantly more likely to have Council Tax arrears compared to where in the UK.ldquoWe are seeing a record level of demand for help with problem debt with over a third of our clients having an additional vulnerability, such as illness.ldquoWe need more signposting to free debt advice, as the earlier someone gets debt advice the greater their options may be and the less harm they could experience.

title: tapestry-work-finally-set-to-commence
story: THE first stage of work on the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor attraction is set to commence in Galashiels.Stirling-based Ogilvie Construction has been appointed to build the landmark facility for the attraction, which tells the story of Scotland through one of the worldrsquos largest tapestries created by , people from across the country.The announcement represents a signicant delay in construction commencing, with project leaders previously hoping to begin work in October .Work at the site is expected to commence in the coming weeks with the council hoping the new building, designed by leading architectural practice Page Park, will transform Galashiels town centre.The visitor centre will have a wide range of interactive displays and activities as well as exhibitions, events and educational facilities and is part of a broader plan to regenerate Galashiels.The local authority has secured pound. million from the Scottish governments Borders Railway Blueprint towards the pound. million centre.The project has faced signicant opposition - last month we reported that an online poll found  percent of Borderers were opposed to the Great Tapestry of Scotland plans for Galashiels.Councillor Mark Rowley, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Executive Member for Business and Economic Development, remains optimistic about the project. He said: ldquoThis is a hugely exciting time for Galashiels and the Scottish Borders.ldquoI am delighted we now have an experienced and trusted contractor in place to take forward the building of this nationally signicant attraction, with the artist impressions indicating it will be a stunning piece of architecture in Galashiels town centre.ldquoJobs will be created during construction of the facility alongside a wide range of social, economic and educational benefits once the building opens to the public.ldquoHeritage and culture experts predict the centre will attract over , people to Galashiels each year once opened, as well as create  new jobs at the facility.ldquoIn addition, almost pound, of extra spending per year is predicted for the local economy, providing , extra visits to complementary attractions, supporting a further  jobs.ldquoThe Tapestry is the first stage of a wider masterplan to regenerate Galashiels, which is starting to see encouraging developments such as the expansion of local estate agents Cullen Kilshaw into the Transport Interchange and positive community feedback on the Coulterrsquos Candy sculpture.ldquoWith the Jim Clark Museum set to open this year, a pound.million Hawick Conservation Area Regeneration Scheme being announced this month and continued investment in key Scottish Borders events, there are more and more reasons for people to come to the Scottish Borders.,params: .pushScottish Borders Councilrsquos Chief Executive, Tracey Logan, said: ldquoThe Tapestry project partners have been working collaboratively to get to this stage and it is excellent to reach this milestone.ldquoWhile the newly appointed construction team makes plans to start in the coming weeks, we will have a number of tourism professionals from the Live Bordersrsquo team attending VisitScotlandrsquos premier business to business travel trade event Expo this week.Alistair Moffat, a Tapestry trustee, hopes the visitor attraction will help reinvigorate central Galashiels. He said: ldquoThe Great Tapestry of Scotland is an object not only of great beauty and power, it will also act as an engine for renewal.ldquoAs large-scale retail moves to the periphery of towns and cities, it is magnetic cultural attractions like the Tapestry that will bring back le to the centres of these beautul places.ldquoThe huge success of the VA in Dundee, attracting , visitors in six months, doubling estimates, is only the latest example of how well this strategy works.

title: flats-plan-unveiled-for-innerleithen
story: PLANS have been tabled for a -apartment development in Innerleithen.Carlisle-based Cubby Developments want to erect a three-storey building on a former works yard off Peebles Road.As well as the  two-bedroom apartments, the full application is for a rear parking area to cater for  vehicles.The full application will be considered by Scottish Borders Council over the coming weeks.

title: flats-plan-for-selkirk-eye-sore-site
story: FRESH plans have been unveiled for a housing development at a Selkirk eye-sore.Carlisle-based Cubby Construction wants to erect a three-storey block of apartments at The Valley.The former Baptist Church site has become overgrown and derelict over the past few decades.Although planning permission was granted in  for  apartments, the development never began.This new full-application is for eight flats to cater for people with ying needs.And the plans also include a new amenity space to compliment the nearby War Memorial.A spokesman for Cubby Construction said: "The aim of this design is to provide town centre affordable housing for Selkirk, whilst positively contributing to the townscape by developing this gap site."The building form and design aims to respect the amenity and context of all of the surrounding buildings, whilst retaining the existing on street parking by realigning the road edge to Bemersyde Crescent."The key to the proposal is that it improves on the original application by providing Housing for Varying Needs compliant homes, as well as an improved relationship to the context of the conservation area and Selkirkrsquos war memorial."In this regard the proposal provides a new public space which retains the primary boundary feature of the site, and creates a dialogue with memorial, both for the residence of the development, and between the two built forms."The application will be considered over the coming weeks by Scottish Borders Council.

title: unpaid-work-for-gambler-who-caused-bookies-disturbance
story: A -year-old man who caused a disturbance in his local branch of William Hill has been ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work at Selkirk Sherf Court.Peter Morey, of Dalatho Crescent in Peebles, pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting, swearing and screaming, knocking furniture over, striking out at staff members and spitting on the floor in the High Street premises on October .A not guilty plea to attempting to punch an employee was accepted by the Crown.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said the dispute started when a staff member asked Morey for ID as there was an age limit of  to operate a machine in the shop.Morey objected and his mother got involved in the argument as well.

title: 370kgs-of-rubbish-collected-in-galashiels-spring-clean
story: A TOTAL of  bags of rubbish were collected, as well as a trampoline, during Saturdays spring clean in Galashiels.The tidy up, which was organised by community councillor Liz Jardine, attracted more than  volunteers.During the two hour pick-up, between am and noon, several areas around the town and along the banks of the Gala Water were targeted.Joining the volunteers was local MP John Lamont.He told us: "It was fantastic to see so many people turn up for the Galashiels Spring Clean.ldquoWell done to Liz Jardine and the team at the Community Council for organising and making sure everyone had the equipment they need.ldquoThe spring clean was a success in terms of the amount of rubbish picked up, but it also sends out a strong message that the community wonrsquot tolerate littering.The collected rubbish, which included  discarded tree supports and even a garden pergola, weighed in at  kilogrammes.Lizs son, councillor Euan Jardine, was delighted the tidy up.He added: "Thank you to everyone that got involved in the spring clean."Itrsquos was great to see so many dferent parts of the community come together for one common goal.ldquoI think Galashiels is a beautul town and it really is a shame when people do not think of the consequences of their littering.ldquoHowever, the volunteers on Saturday really showed that when people work together we can really make a dference to the town we live in.

title: hawick-pump-track-given-go-ahead
story: PLANS for a pound, pump track in Hawick have been given the go-ahead by council planners.The pump track, which will feature ramps, jumps and banked corners for bikes, will be situated on the site of the former tennis courts in Wilton Lodge Park, and is being pushed forward by the Hawick Community Pump Track group.The group has already received pound, from Scottish Borders Council, which also owns the former tennis courts, and is currently fundraising to make up the extra cash.Ben Wilson, the grouprsquos secretary, said: ldquoThe committee are absolutely enthralled about the news this being a pretty big milestone.ldquoWersquove put in a lot of work over the past years and itrsquos great when you get news of successful effort, wersquove still a fair way to go but itrsquos one step closer.ldquoThis planning permission has opened up opportunities to tap into certain funds that need planning as a requirement.ldquoThe facility will be available to use from kids on balance bikes all the way to as old as you like.ldquoThe facility itself comprises of two tracks. One smaller track for kids on balance bikes and people new to the sport, which encourages progression in skills enabling them to move onto the larger track.ldquoEven the larger track has progression from learners to elite riders, offering something for all.ldquoThe benefits to the community of the town are great especially the often forgotten about teenagers.ldquoThis facility offers a place to engage in a sport improving social skills alongside health and well-being.The group has plans to install floodlights for the track, but this will need separate planning permission, and a bat survey is due to be carried out in May which will likely decide the fate of the application.Mr Wilson added that although this is a major milestone for the group, they havenrsquot set an opening date: ldquoIn terms of opening I couldnrsquot commit to a date at this stage as it is all dependant on successful funding.ldquoWhen we have everything in place there will be plenty of time to publicise and create a hype.

title: earlston-family-hopes-to-help-other-grieving-parents-with-joes-toes
story: A DEVASTATED Earlston family is hoping to ease the pain for other grieving parents by undertaking a series of spring and summer challenges.And all proceeds from their fundraising will go towards creating lasting mementoes for mums and dads to remember their lost babies.Last February Keith and Marie Briggs welcomed identical twins into the world - eight weeks early.Thomas Joseph Briggs, known as Tommy, was born first, shortly before his twin brother Joseph, known as Joe, who was sadly stillborn as a result of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.Tommy spent five weeks in hospital and was cared for both in the Special Care Baby Unit at Borders General Hospital and the Simpsons Neonatal Intensive Care Unitat the Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh.During those weeks before Tommy was finally allowed home, the Briggs family was supported by the Childrenrsquos Hospices Across ScotlandDiana nurse Evelyn Rodger.Evelyn has remained an invaluable support ever since.Part of her role as a Diana Nurse is to provide bereavement support and to help parents find ways to create lasting memories of their babies.Marie told us: ldquoEvelyn is a compassionate, kind, gentle woman who is incredibly knowledgeable in bereavement care and we feel privileged that she was there to support us in making cherished memories with Joe and with saying goodbye with no regrets.ldquoAs part of the memory making process, we askedshe would be able to help us take D casts of Joersquos feet."Evelyn was more than willing to help us in any way she could."Joersquos cast is now one of our most cherished possessions and to be able to physically touch, hold, see, something that was exactly his is so very precious.ldquoOur little Joe has given us, and now other families, so much without even being here."He never drew breath but he has changed us forever. He has reminded us all of how precious and fragile le can be."Every day is a challenge but he has already shown us that we have a strength within us inidually and as a family that can move mountains."May he always know how much he was wished for, longed for, prayed for and wanted.In Scotland, more than , children and young people live with le-shortening conditions and CHAS provides its hospice services nationwide for many of the babies, children and young people from Rachel House in Kinross and Robin House in Balloch.A D cast service is available within the CHAS hospices, but the Joes Toes project will take the mementoes into neonatal units - providing an opportunity for many more parents to make precious lasting memories following the death of their baby.All funds raised by the Joes Toes project will allow CHAS to purchase materials required to make the D baby hand and foot-casts.In the coming months, the Briggs familyrsquos fundraising group will tackle the -mile Tour de Lauder cycling challenge, which will include an extra  miles to make it to Borders General Hospital, the Edinburgh half marathon, the Great North Run, the Loch Ness Marathon and also hosting a ladies cocktail night in the summer.,params: .pushThey are currently halfway towards raising their pound, target.Fiona Leslie, who is the community fundraiser at CHAS, added: ldquoAlong with Marie and Evelyn, we are currently designing a beautul box that families will be able to put their castings in to transport home and keep safe."We canrsquot thank Marie, Keith, their family and friends enough for taking on this awesome summer of fundraisers for this particularly special project."The funds they raise and this idea in itself will help bring comfort to so many families. Itrsquos a lovely legacy for their little boy.Anyone wishing to sponsor the Briggs family can go to https:give.everydayhero uk joe-s-toes

title: sbc-defends-non-disclosure-of-damning-lowood-report
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has defended not disclosing a damning report which condemned plans for developing Lowood Estate, ahead of a decision to splash out more than pound million was approved.The report, produced by the property consultancy firm Jones Lang LaSalle , determined that the Lowood portion of the Tweedbank masterplan is ldquounviable and undeliverable and that ldquoit is quite clear that what is proposed is over-development of the site.The damning report, commissioned by Middlemede Properties Ltd, who own the Upper Pavilion fishing beat adjacent to the proposed Lowood development, was presented to SBC chiefs months before the council purchased the land for pound. million in December .Once costs of borrowing and other fees have been factored in, the purchase will cost SBC around pound million and forms parts of its wider plan to address a regional housing shortfall of some  units.The Lowood site has been earmarked for around  properties, however the JLL report suggests that the development is unlikely to yield any financial gain.The report claims: ldquoOur conclusion is that there would be insufficient revenue to generate either a developerrsquos profit or a positive land value.In addition to questioning the economic viability of the development, the JLL report raises concerns that ldquothe level of development and infrastructure proposed would seriously harm the environment and the River Tweed interests from a physical and amenity perspective.Stuart Bell, SBC Councillor for Tweeddale East, told the Borderthat he nor other voting councillors were not given access to the report prior to rubber-stamping the planned purchase of the land.He said: ldquoI was unaware of this report and its conclusions when the decision was taken by Scottish Borders Council to purchase the Lowood Estate.ldquoI think that many other Borders councillors were similarly in ignorance of it which is worrying given the signicance of its conclusions that the Lowood proposal is over-development and not commercially viable.ldquoThis does seem strange to me when the report is dated March  and I understand it was passed to council officers.ldquoGiven the potential signicance of the analysis and conclusions I have written to SBC officers asking for clarication on why this report was not brought immediately to the attention of councillors.Scottish Borders Council has defended both the report not being tabled and also the purchase of the picturesque estate.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe JLL report was produced as a response to the Housing Supplementary Guidance document which the council was required to produce as part of the Local Development Plan.ldquoHowever, it was not submitted to the council until after the expiry of the public consultation period and after the Guidance had been considered and approved by the council in August .,params: .pushldquoThere was therefore no opportunity for it to be presented to Councillors when they agreed to allocate Lowood for development.ldquoThe viability of development at Lowood Estate was thoroughly reviewed in a series of subsequent technical reports that formed the basis of the recommendations made to councillors in private on May , .ldquoThe report considered by Members in March  contained detailed analysis including a thorough consideration of market conditions which went signicantly beyond the scope of the JLL report.ldquoWe remain satisfied that the basis of the recommendations to and decisions made by councillors on May  is robust and includes a comprehensive review of all relevant issues contained in the JLL report.ldquoWe believe this vital site is capable of delivering an estimated  jobs, as part of a wider masterplan for Tweedbank which could create over  jobs for the Scottish Borders.

title: selkirk-couples-dazzling-success-with-innovative-sunglasses
story: BEING dazzled by the sun is now a thing of the past thanks to new light adapting sunglasses from Borders business.KomodoPro sunglasses can adapt to the sunrsquos rays in less than a second and are being targeted at game shooters as an essential piece of kit.Mick and Anna Bell are currently in their second year of selling the sunglasses.The couple currently live in the Ettrick Valley after moving up from London to escape the corporate world.They now run three businesses, the most notable of which is Bloke Fly Rods, which reach customers worldwide from their office in Selkirk.Mick and Anna have attended ious trade shows across the UK to promote KomodoPro and have sold out at each one in the last  months.The Scottish Game Fair, held at Scone Palace, was the most successful show for the pair in .The fair was held over three days, but by pm on the first day the KomodoPro dhelf was emptied and a hunt for more stock took place.The next event the couple will be attending is the Northern Shooting Show in Harrogate on May  and , where they intend to continue their success from the past year.Currently they have exclusive UK distribution for the Japanese innovation, which retail at pound per pair.Mick Bell told us: ldquoKomodoPro is a revolutionary new product which is perfect for game shooting.ldquoWhat makes the sunglasses unique is that they are so fast they make a stepless change between light and dark."You canrsquot see it happening.ldquoLast year was great for us and now we are predicting more success in the coming year."Standard photochromic sunglasses take up to  seconds to adapt to light compared to KomodoPro which take an astonishing one-tenth of a second, making them stand out against competitors.The sunglasses use a solar powered sensor to detect the level of UV light.And each lens has a wire and a microchip that assesses how much UV inflection is taken in by the sunglasses.For more information on KomodoPro you can visit www.komodopro

title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet Of The Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, is five-year-old Pal.The charity told us: "Pal came in to us as his owner was struggling to cope with him. He needs to be the only pet in a home without children but he is a happy boy so will make a great companion for someone. Poor Pal has already had at least three homes before coming in to our care, so his next home needs to be his forever home."Pal hasnrsquot had much basic training although he does have pretty good recall and he is clever, so picks up on training easily. He is looking for a home where he can get this much-needed training and he definitely needs an active home where he can get plenty of exercise and stimulation. His favourite thing is chasing a tennis ball!"If you would like to offer Pal his forever home, please email info@borderspetrescue.org for an application."

title: local-authority-top-brass-are-rolling-in-it
story: THE pay of Scottish Borders Councilrsquos top executives has been revealed.In total, the councilrsquos six highest earning executives were paid more than half a million pounds, with the councilrsquos chief executive Tracey Logan taking home pound, in  .The local authorityrsquos next highest paid employee, SB Caresrsquo managing director Philip Barr, was paid pound,, while services director Rob Dickson received remuneration of pound,.Donna Manson, who was the service director for children and young people before moving to Highland Council to become a chief executive, was paid pound,, and chief financial officer David Robertson was paid pound,.Finally, Martin Joyce, the service director of assets and infrastructure, was paid pound, for his services.However, the chief executive and other directors agreed to a voluntary pay freeze in  in order to help with council cutbacks.The figures have been released by the TaxPayersrsquo Alliance, a right wing pressure group that campaigns for a low tax society, as part of its annual townhall rich list.John OrsquoConnell, the chief executive of the TaxPayersrsquo Alliance, said: ldquoThe average council tax bill has gone up by more than pound over the last twenty years and spending has gone through the roof.ldquoDisappointingly, many local authorities are now responding to financial reality through further tax rises and reducing services rather than scaling back top pay.ldquoDespite many in the public sector facing a much-needed pay freeze to help bring the public finances under control, many town hall bosses are continuing to pocket huge remuneration packages, with staggering pay-outs for those leaving their jobs.ldquoThere are talented people in the public sector who are trying to deliver more for less, but the sheer scale of these packages raise serious questions about efficiency and priorities.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoScottish Borders Council has reduced the number of officers paid salaries of over pound, in recent years, from four in   to the current number of two.ldquoSalary levels at Scottish Borders Council are set by reference to national agreements and reflect the scale and responsibility associated with the management of a complex public sector organisation with gross annual turnover of poundm.ldquoThe council is well aware of the challenging financial times we are faced with. This is why we have over several years made decisions to help protect our frontline services and our staff.The spokesperson added that Tracey Loganrsquos salary is lower than the majority of other local authority chief executives in Scotland, with  out of the  Scottish chief executives drawing a higher annual salary.

title: 28-year-old-admits-causing-disturbances-in-galashiels-and-walkerburn
story: A -year-old man has been banned from a Galashiels pub until the outcome of his case.Neil Brown appeared from custody at Selkirk Sherf Court and pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in the Harrow Inn in High Street on Wednesday, April .He also admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in Tweedholm Avenue, Walkerburn, on Friday, April , as well as attempting to self-harm and attempting to assault a police officer.Sentence was deferred until May  for background reports.He was granted bail to an address in Edinburgh with the special conditions not to enter the Harrow Inn or Tweedholm Avenue as well as not contacting three named family members.

title: greggs-submits-plans-to-develop-galashiels-eyesore
story: GREGGS has submitted an application to develop a Galashiels eyesore.The bakery chain is hoping to open a new store at the former Ozkans Grill takeaway in Market Street.Andsuccessful, it would have an outdoor seating area for customers.Over the last few months, the town centre site has been targeted by vandals.Since the takeaway closed, windows have been smashed and the store front covered with graffiti.But proposals submitted to Scottish Borders Council this week show Greggs is hoping to give the unit a facelt and would install four tables and  chairs in the outdoor seating area.The chain, which was launched in Newcastle in , has around , shops nationwide including one in Channel Street.However, it is not yet clearthat would remain openthe plans were given the go-ahead.The firm also has stores in Hawick, Kelso and Peebles.The Borderhas contacted Greggs for comment.

title: housebuilder-apologises-after-admitting-responsibility-for-defective-peebles-homes
story: ONE of the countrys largest housebuilding firms has finally issued an apology to Peebles homeowners.For over two years seven families living on the Kingsmeadows development have been battling with the builders over defects caused by crumbling mortar.Earlier this year Taylor Wimpey acknowledged, as part of its full year results statement, concerns regarding mortar durability and added that a "robust technical solution" to fix the problem had been identied.Work has already started on the affected  properties and this week, the company offered an apology.A Taylor Wimpey spokesperson told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoWe sincerely apologise to the affected homeowners for the issues that they have experienced within some homes at our Kingsmeadow development in Peebles."While a signicant number of houses on the development are unaffected by mortar issues, a robust technical solution to fix the durability of the mortar has been identied, which is supported by our appointed structural engineer, an independent review by the Scottish Borders Council, and the National House Building Council."We have a clear plan in place to remediate affected homes and works have already begun on the development.Problems first emerged with houses on the Kingsmeadows development in .Scottish Borders Councils building standards officers were contacted as well as Taylor Wimpey.The developer bought back several properties from householders after faults were identied.Non-disclosure agreements prevented the families from discussing the issues.In  more concerns were raised with the local authority over public safety on the development.And Tracey Logan, chief executive of Scottish Borders Council, called a meeting with Taylor Wimpey bosses where it was agreed for an independent structural engineer to carry out surveys.Although no structural issues were identied during the surveys of randomly selected properties the developer acknowledged there were problems with mortar on some houses.And towards the end of last year they sent out letters offering to carry out remedial action.A spokesperson for Scottish Borders Council told us: "The first public safety concerns were raised with the council in late ."In response to these concerns, the Chief Executive requested a meeting with Taylor Wimpey to investigate the concerns."At this meeting, it was agreed that an independent structural engineer would be commissioned to carry out structural surveys in a number of randomly selected properties."This was carried out in summer ."The council did not have an official role in this process, but it was considered important to provide an independent opinion on the situation to ensure that any concerns were identied and addressed effectively and consider whether there was any public safety risk."The report identied no structural issues with the inspected houses and was satisfied with Taylor Wimpeyrsquos proposed remedial action to repair potential defects,required, andthe owners wished to take up this offer, which we understand a number of residents have."A BBC investigations team identied that the Peebles housing development was one of  across the country where inferior mortar had been used.Sheila Chalmers and her husband recruited their own structural engineers to carry out assessments on their Peebles home - and both contradicted a Taylor Wimpey survey identying extensive repairs were required.And, along with six other families from the Kingsmeadows development, Mr and Mrs Chalmers continued to campaign for the developer to admit responsibility and fix the structural problems.Mrs Chalmers told the BBC: "These developers, these companies, cannot be allowed to continue the destruction of peoples lives with building shoddy homes."Somebody has to stand up and show them that they cannot get away with it."

title: local-politicians-react-to-brexit-extension
story: LOCAL politicians have reacted to the news that the Brexit withdrawal deadline has been delayed until October .The extension was approved by EU leaders following protracted talks in Brussels last night, averting the immediate threat of the UK leaving without a deal.Under the extension agreement the UK is now dutybound to hold European elections in May, although the country could still exit the EU before OctoberTheresa May can secure parliamentary support for her withdrawal agreement.David Mundell, Scottish Secretary and MP for Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale, was pleased with the extension but warned of hard work ahead. He said: ldquoFirst and foremost, Irsquom pleased we have avoided leaving the EU without a deal.ldquoMy top priority all along has been to avoid a no-deal Brexit and the disruption it would cause.ldquoDelaying Brexit is not ideal, but Parliament has so far failed to support a withdrawal deal that would allow us to leave in an orderly fashion.ldquoWe have to continue working to achieve that.ldquoDonald Tusk, the President of the European Council, has urged us not to waste this extra time. He is right.ldquoWe have avoided no-deal, but we still have a lot of work to do.MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, Christine Grahame, has demanded that Theresa May holds a second EU referendum and reaffirmed her desire for Scottish independence.She said: ldquoThis extension will come as a relief to those who feared us crashing out without a deal on Friday, however the key question is what is done during this extension - Scotlandrsquos interests must be protected.ldquoTheresa May must use this time to hold a fresh EU referendum with the option to Remain on the ballot paper.ldquoThe Borders did not vote for Brexit and should not be forced to accept a Brexit deal put together by Labour and the Tories ndash parties that have ignored Scotlandrsquos voice and interests every step of the way.ldquoIf Labour helps the Tories push through their plans to leave the Single Market, ending freedom of movement - which will cost jobs and hit public services in the Borders and where - they will not be forgiven at the ballot box in Scotland.ldquoThe UK governmentrsquos Brexit fiasco shows clearly that the Borders and indeed Scotlandrsquos interests are best protected through independence.

title: prestonpans-shop-could-feature-on-bbc-show
story: Corner Shop Cook Off is coming to screens across the country to show off the importance of local convenience stores in Scotland.The new show is presented by actress and musician Clare Grogan, with winner of MasterChef The Professionals Gary Maclean as the resident chef.Each week, a prominent Scottish chef will guest star, going head to head with Gary, only using ingredients from a selected local convenience store from around the country.The Day-Today on Redburn Road in Prestonpans has been selected as a possible store to feature on the show and,it is picked, the BBC portable kitchen will be set up in Prestonpans Town Hall for the event next month.The BBC said that it wanted the local shop owner and the customers to be the judges, adding: ldquoThis means we can really get into the heart of towns all over Scotland and show how essential the local convenience store really isIf confirmed, Corner Shop Cook Off will be filmed on April  and  in Prestonpans Town Hall.

title: celebrations-as-prestonpans-charity-elcap-marks-its-30th-birthday
story: The Lighthouse Hub hosted the event with a buffet, guest speakers and local musicians.Even microphone problems and a broken slideshow couldnrsquot dampen the mood as the birthday bash opened with two pipers from Preston Lodge High School Pipe Band.Bette Francis, member of the ELCAP board, hosted the event, introducing the speakers: chief executive Paul White, ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, and lastly a moving testimony from fellow board member Kirstin Doherty.Paul White, who was appointed chief executive five months ago, started the talks by outlining the importance that ELCAP played within communities, a point that was reiterated by guest speaker Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell.The final speaker, Kirstin Doherty, a member of the ELCAP board, has been supported by the charity since . Her speech closed off the formal side of the event and she outlined how ELCAP had helped her move out of her parentsrsquo house, go on holiday and gain more independence.ldquoThey have helped me achieve more than I ever thought possible, she concluded.Kirstin, along with Ms OrsquoDonnell and Bette Francis, then proceeded to cut the cake to a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo from the guests.Attending the event was Linda Headland, the first chief executive of ELCAP in , a position she held until .ldquoItrsquos always good to know that you can leave something in good hands, she said.ldquoWhen ELCAP started, we always believed that it was about giving people a le, not just an existence, and that still stands to this day.ldquoItrsquos all about finding new ways to bring people in to the community.The charity, which is based in Prestonpans, will be hosting two other events this year to celebrate its th birthday, including one in June at the Scottish Parliament.

title: east-lothian-council-lar-housing-rejected
story: Housing charity LAR had applied to build four houses and  flats on the land, which is designated for business use, in Prestonpans but has failed to find an employer to take it on.Despite a personal plea from the charityrsquos chief executive and an admission that East Lothian Council had tried to buy the site for housing itself just two years ago, the affordable housing bid was rejected at a meeting of the councilrsquos planning committee on Tuesday.The decision came despite LAR revealing it had invested pound, in preparing plans for the site after it was told the council would consider a change of use.Chief executive Ann Leslie told the committee that out of  homes built or under construction by the charity since it began,  had been in East Lothian and there were currently  people on its waiting list to move into one in the county.And she revealed the charity has been considering moving its base to East Lothian.She said: ldquoWe are very keen to support East Lothian as much as we are able to bring as many affordable homes as we can. There is a big waiting list in the county and we hope to open a base here.But planning officers urged councillors to reject LARrsquos proposals, regardless of their own efforts to build housing there two years ago.Iain McFarlane, head of planning, said that two years ago the council did not have its Local Development Plan approved and faced a shortage of land for affordable housing.Now the plan had been adopted, he said there was sufficient land supply for the next five years.He said allowing housing on the site would set an ldquoundesirable precedent, adding it would be ldquoselling our employment plans down the river.Councillor Kenny McLeod, committee member, said he was ldquodeeply uncomfortable about refusing planning permission on a site the council had tried to develop in the same way two years ago.At the time, council officers said the landowner rejected their pound, offer as too low.Robin Holder, representing LAR at the meeting, said the council had given written reassurance it would consider the site, which has lain empty since , for housing.He rejected claims that approving the plans would set a precedent, saying: ldquoThis is a small area, this site is a quarter of one per cent of land identied for industrial use in East Lothian. The site has been vacant for many years and the evidence suggests it will remain so.But Councillor Norman Hampshire said: ldquoI cannot support the application: it would send a message to other owners of land designated for business use.The committee rejected the planning application by six votes to three.Following the meeting, Ms Leslie said: ldquoNaturally we are disappointed at the decision and are considering whether to appeal against it.ldquoWe have worked very closely with East Lothian Council over the last three years on a number of projects to enhance the provision of good-quality affordable homes in the area and have enjoyed a very positive working relationship with them.ldquoOur proposal for Prestonpans was a design and build project for  homes, very similar to our recently completed development at the disused site of the former boatyard in Cockenzie. This proved to be extremely popular and was vastly oversubscribed, so there is an urgent need for homes like ours.ldquoWe understand that this site in Prestonpans had been earmarked for commercial use but, in the absence of any confirmed interest, we had hoped that our plans, which would enhance the local environment and provide much-needed affordable housing, would have been supported.

title: woman-was-five-and-a-half-times-over-drink-drive-limit-in-prestonpans
story: Gayle Duffy has been banned for  months after she was caught with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at High Street, Prestonpans.The legal limit is just mcg.Duffy, of Clark Avenue, was also sentenced to a -day restriction of liberty order meaning she must stay within her home address between pm and am for the duration of the order.The -year-old had previously admitted the offence and she was sentenced at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday.Duffy admitted drink-driving on February .

title: asbo-bans-musselburgh-woman-from-abusive-behaviour
story: The ASBO was granted against Vivienne Stewart, , of Stoneybank Gardens South, following an application to Edinburgh Sherf Court by East Lothian Council.The court was presented with details of the alleged anti-social behaviour of Ms Stewart, which included shouting and swearing, excessive noise and reports of late-night disturbances.The terms of the ASBO ban her from behaving in a way that causes or is likely to cause alarm or distress to others, including playing a radio, TV or other sound-producing devices at anti-social levels, as well as shouting, swearing or using threatening, intimidating, aggressive or abusive language or behaviour within her home.A council spokesperson said: ldquoEast Lothian Council, with the support of Police Scotland, will not hesitate in taking robust action against those whose behaviour causes alarm and distress to others.

title: msp-hopeful-of-vastly-improved-service-at-musselburgh-gp-surgery
story: The group was highlighted by Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, who recently met Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, following ldquooverwhelming public concern regarding the serious lack of appointments to see a doctor and the poor level of service offered by the practice.Mr Beattie stated that a spokesperson from the medical practice, which is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, indicated that ldquoimprovements in the way patients are being cared for in Musselburgh are in the process of being made.Early evaluation of the way services were being delivered since the launch of the Collaborative Working for Immediate Care service ndash run by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipand the merged Eskbridge and Riverside Medical Practices ndash demonstrated that patients who previously would have seen a GP were now seeing the right clinician at the right time for their specic needs.The new service, developed in partnership by Riverside, NHS  and ELHSCP, ensured that urgent care was dealt with on the same day and patients should have ldquono anxieties about being seen by the right professional at the right time.Through this new way of delivering patient care, it not only provided an increase in the number of patient appointments with practice GPs and other healthcare professionals, but also provided an increase in appointmentfor patients with complex needs.A recent survey conducted within the practice demonstrated that more than half of patients agreed that they did not always need to see a GP.Work is also under way by ELHSCP to implement a new telephone and IT system that will support call demand into the practice.The importance of patient involvement in getting services right is ldquovery much recognised by the practice, which is encouraging residents to get involved with the Patient Participation Group.Speaking after meeting with the Cabinet Secretary, Mr Beattie said: ldquoI would like to assure all of my constituents that patient care is of paramount importance and that all agencies involved in the new way services are being delivered within Musselburgh Primary Care Centre are focused on delivering the best care possible.ldquoRiverside Medical Practice is working with other organisations to ensure that improvements are made and I would encourage anyone with any issues regarding the practice to get in touch with them and become involved with the patient participation group.ldquoI am hopeful that the improvements being made by the organisations will be seen by patients and a vastly improved service will be delivered.ldquoI will continue to closely monitor the future performance of the practice and ask patients to keep me advised on whether the improvements are working.

title: seatbelt-embarrassment-spurs-on-musselburgh-couple-to-big-weight-loss
story: Derek Melon, , a customer services advisor, and his we Carole, , a mortgage advisor, of James Street, are both feeling ldquofantastic after their bumper weight loss, which was sparked by a holiday to Florida.Derek has dropped five stones from st lbs to st lbs, and Carole, who weighed in at st lbs, lost four-and-a-half stones to get to st lbs since they joined Weight Watchers in June last year.Their journey started after the couple, who have a teenage son, booked a holiday to Florida.Carole said: ldquoI was so excited but the plane journey going left me feeling humiliated and not happy as I had to request a seatbelt extension as I could not fasten the original seatbelt. Thankfully no one heard me asking for it but the embarrassment of having to ask was enough to spur me on.ldquoAt this point, on what should have been an exciting time, I was left feeling down, and it was then that I decided that it was time to lose weight.ldquoNever again did I want to be in that position of asking for an extension. The next time I was flying I wanted to be able to buckle up like any other person.ldquoWhen I ed, I decided to join Weight Watchers at Musselburgh Hope Church, and it was the best decision I have ever made.ldquoI have now lost more than four-and-a-half stones and feel fantastic. I find the Weight Watchers app amazing as its so easy to use and being able to track is really simple and motivating.ldquoI am a very fussy eater, and, on the plan, I can still have a treatI want. This makes le easy and no one really knows you are on a healthy eating plan as I can eat just like everyone .ldquoEverything about the Freestyle plan just suits me, and, even though I donrsquot eat meat or fish, I can still eat a lot of what I like.ldquoThe weekly workshops are very motivational and I love going. My wellness coach, Lisa Stewart, is so supportive, as well as all the other members.ldquoNow I can make the right choices, walk more and shop for clothes that I would never have been able to buy before. Clothes shopping has also become really enjoyable and less expensive as I no longer need to buy a size  but a rather smaller size .ldquoWalking has now become easier as I used to get breathless but this does not happen now. I have the motivation to keep going even when Irsquove put weight on as Irsquom not perfect.Derek was inspired to lose weight by Carole, saying: ldquoMy we joined Weight Watchers and her initial weight loss was inspiring. I knew I had to lose weight but I just never had the motivation to do anything about it.ldquoMy we was looking amazing and it was then that I knew it was time for me to get on the Weight Watchers wagon. Irsquom so glad I joined with Carole as I find it easy to follow.ldquoI can still eat my favourite snacks ndash crisps ndash which is something I was not prepared to give up. Thankfully I can enjoy these and still lose weight.ldquoDoing the Freestyle plan with Carole is really good although we do not always eat the same foods. The choice of foods that we can enjoy and eat means both us can enjoy what we want.ldquoThe support from the coach Lisa is fantastic and sometimes Irsquom the only male who stays for the weekly talk. This does not phase me as my weight loss is too important and everyone is really friendly. Even when my we canrsquot make it, I go on my own. Men should not be afraid of joining as Irsquove had a fantastic weight loss.ldquoMy food choices are now better and I pay more attention to what I eat. We both used to eat things like large bars of chocolate, deep-pan pizzas, lots of bread and cheese. There was no thought to what we were eating.ldquoWe now eat better with lots of fresh fruit and veg, and have more thought in what we are preparing and eating and are both enjoying our food much better.He added: ldquoA big tick to myself is that I can now buy jeans in Primark ndash something I was not able to do before. It sounds silly but being able to go and buy a  waist instead of a -inch waist just makes me smile. My top size used to be an XXXL but can now buy a size XL L, so itrsquos quite clear why I enjoy buying new clothes.

title: new-tenants-take-over-cafe-at-dunbars-lauderdale-park
story: Bev Anderson and John Semple, , signed the lease for the cafe in Lauderdale Park last week and are already busy working to get the business open for around Easter.The couple run the Wishing Tree Play Cafe on Musselburgh High Street, which they will operate alongside the Dunbar business, named Wishing Tree... By The Sea.Bev said: ldquoWe have had the Wishing Tree coming up for four years.ldquoI actually had signed the lease four years ago for the Wishing Tree and three weeks later the lease came up on [Lauderdale Park].ldquoAt that stage, I did not think I was in a position to do it.ldquoI have been coming to Dunbar for a long number of years and had a caravan at Pease Bay.ldquoWe moved to the area and I used to take my daughters to the park. We used to play there all the time and go to the cafe and I always loved the setting and thought it had so much potential.Now, with the Wishing Tree up and running, Bev and husband John, of the townrsquos Countess Road, are excitedly working on transforming the building.A takeaway hatch is being installed, with plans for a vintage ice cream bike and ice cream to be sold.Bev, who hopes to create at least three jobs in Dunbar, said: ldquoThe reality is it is going to be fresh home-baking and local produce.ldquoWe are targeting as much local produce as we can and there are a lot of good things going on in the area.ldquoThere will be fresh homemade salads, the healthy side of things, but there will be sweets and treats as well.The business hopes to be open in time for the European Stone Stacking Championships, which takes place in the town on April  and .Bev, , will run the cafe and was keen to get involved in community events, with the possibility of food markets also being considered.The business will be open five days a week during term time and throughout the week during the holidays.Bev said: ldquoThere are a lot of local events in Dunbar.ldquoThere is Civic Week and other things and we are really keen to be part of the existing programme. There is so much going on in Dunbar and we want to be adding wee things in the future.

title: businesses-in-north-berwick-urged-to-let-people-use-their-toilet
