title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: Rosemary Goring  Don   t let us be banished by Brexit to the back of beyond
story: Known as The Virgin with the Laughing Child, and about  inches high, it was made around , when Leonardo was a young apprentice in Verrocchiorsquos workshop in Florence. Galleries, and indeed this very exhibition, are stuffed to the rafters with paintings and sculptures of the Madonna and Child. You canrsquot help feeling artists must have grown as weary of this subject as of the Crucixion and the Last Supper. But, since the Church was their main source of income, these iconic images prolerated. Naturally, the finest artists, like Verrocchio, Filippo Lippi and Raphael, took this image and transformed it into a profound portrait of their times, pushing the art form to its limits.Clearly Leonardo also stretched himself from the outset. The baby in the Virgin Maryrsquos lap is chortling, gurgling so realistically you want to laugh with him. His mother, too, looks quietly amused, her mouth reminiscent of the Mona Lisarsquos enigmatic smile. Verrocchiorsquos influence is apparent in this cheery representation, since his sculptures of cherubs and children were often merry. But for Leonardo to portray the Christ child like this was positively revolutionary. This image would have been viewed by some as heretical in the th century, that was not a charge anyone who hoped for a long and productive le wished to have pinned to them.This gem, by one of the greatest geniuses who ever lived, is a reminder of the early days of Florencersquos influence and power. Leonardo was one of a handful of brilliant artists who ignited the Renaissance. Teeming with rich patrons, like the Medici and the Strozzi, and with thousands of churches and chapels needing walls covered and altarpieces filled, the capital of Tuscany was the furnace in which modern art was forged. Without the unparalleled explosion of talent in Leonardorsquos and Michelangelorsquos time, the cityrsquos fortunes would have been very dferent. Who knows what it would look like today.It makes sense, then, that Florence is twinned with Edinburgh, a pairing that dates back to . One created the Renaissance, the other lit the fuse beneath the Enlightenment, which was to rip through Europe, setting it alight. Florence showcased Brunelleschi, Giotto and Ghiberti, while its northern partner nurtured David Hume and Adam Smith. One appealed to the senses, the other to the intellect. Both are founded on banking and finance, their hearts beating in time with the stock market. Each is obsessed with status, class, and appearances. The upper echelons can be chilly and aloof, and in their grand villas and offices it is old money that talks loudest. The nouveau riche will gain entry, but never acceptance. Nor is it coincidence that, floating on so much wealth, both are exquisitely beautul.Many years ago, when Labour was in power at Holyrood, there was talk of enhancing the twin-city link, and to this end a formal partnership that encompassed all of Tuscany and Scotland was proposed. I recall my selfless husband stopping the First Minister in the street and offering to become ambassador to Tuscany, evenit meant being posted to Florence. He said hersquod do it for free, yet strangely, nothing came of it.Wersquore in far more serious times now, of course. With the bond that connects us to Europe soon to be cut, is this not the moment to deepen the relationship with our Tuscan twin  If we could build on our friendship, and on our many mutual interests, we would counter at least some of the damage caused by being set adrt from the EU. Economic blight is bad enough, but to be severed from a region whose culture and people have immeasurably shaped ours is more insidiously harmful. What an oasis of civilisation and culture Florence and the rest of Tuscany would offer to those of us feeling left out in the cold. In turn, we could offer a bridge into Britain, showing that we have not turned our back on our continental European heritage, but are eager to keep it close.Read more: Should we tourists take note of Italys gathering storm To do so would offer tangible results, for both sides. There are many forms it could take, from cultural exchanges, intellectual liaisons and trading or commercial enterprises to environmental partnerships ndash Florence was at the forefront of banning cars in the city centre ndash or historical and artistic projects. The benefits would ripple out. Perhaps as importantly as any pragmatic outcome, however, working more closely with our twin city and twin region would be a statement of intent. We refuse to be banished by Brexit to the back of beyond.

title: plane-takes-off-after-air-traffic-controllers-had-left-for-home
story: The scheduled Loganair flight left Kirkwall for Edinburgh after the airportrsquos tower had closed amid a work-to-rule dispute.A whistleblower said the plane was only able to get off the ground after a ground crew member entered the tower and switched on the runway lights. The incident, last Friday night, is now being investigated by the Civil Aviation Authority .:Glasgow flight plummeted towards the ground after wrong autopilot was selectedBoth Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd , which operates Kirkwall Airport, and Loganair have said that there was no breach of either rules or aircraft safety and that both companies were investigating the circumstances of the flight, where air traffic controllers would normally be monitoring activities.HIALrsquos air traffic controllers are working to rule ndash including not staying beyond airport opening hoursa plane is delayed ndash because of a pay dispute.The plane, which was carrying three crew as well as its passengers, took off at .pm, an hour behind schedule and  minutes after controllers clocked off.The whistleblower said that the airport was closed and therefore legally unlicensed and that no commercial aircraft could operate from an unlicensed airport without CAA approval.The incident triggered mutual accusations of intransigence on the part of HIAL and that the aircraft controllers had exceeded the legal bounds of their agreed industrial action.Orkney and Shetland MP Alistair Carmichael said he had written to the CAA demanding an investigation as only a thorough probe of events could get to the truth of what happened.Mr Carmichael added: ldquoI am very concerned about the content of what I have been told and want an early answer from the CAA about what they intend to do as the regulator of this area. It obviously concerns me because the safety of the people travelling throughout the Highlands and Islands is absolutely paramount and, on the face of it, this is a very serious breach of the proper procedures.:Loganiar plane involved in near miss with drone at Glasgow AirportThe disagreement between HIAL and the air traffic controllers union Prospect hinges on the hours that should have been covered, with HIAL and Loganair claiming the controllers were rostered till .pm and the controllers saying their hours concluded at .pm.A spokesman for HIAL said that the decision to carry on with the flight had been an operational one, with ground management and the pilot deciding it was safe to fly.He said: ldquoThe flight was able to depart following a dynamic risk assessment undertaken by Loganairrsquos flight operations management in conjunction with HIAL. Recognised safety procedures were followed before the aircraft departed safely and completed its schedule to Edinburgh.A spokesman for Loganair said that the plane departed ldquousing alternative procedures available to pilots to fly without local air traffic control support at Kirkwall.The CAA, meanwhile, confirmed the organisation was aware of the incident adding that it was ldquocurrently looking into the circumstances.Prospect negotiations officer David Avery said it would be wrong to comment on the specics of the incident while an investigation was ongoing.He added: ldquoIf a flight with passengers has departed without air traffic control that would be very serious and the CAA would need to look into the matter urgently..Loganair managing director Jonathan Hinkles said Friday eveningrsquos actions were ldquobeyond the scope of the dispute notied by Prospect.He also thanked the HIAL safety teams and Loganairrsquos crew for ensuring customers complete their planned flight despite the ldquounforeseen and unnecessary turn of events. Loganair said it notied the CAA after the event as it was an ldquounusual circumstance but all parties were ldquosatisfied that the operation was safe and legal.

title: theresa-may-wins-six-month-extension-from-eu-on-brexit
story: It came after the Prime Minister vowed to stay on as leader for as long as it takes to deliver her Brexit deal.European leaders wrangled into the night over whether an extension to Brexit should be short ndash until June ndash or long until December or even March .Later this morning, Theresa May is due to give a Commons statement on the EU offer, which the Government was bound to accept because not to do so would have raised the prospect of Britain crashing out of the Brussels bloc at pm tomorrow.At Westminster, the Prime Minister will face a Conservative backlash from angry Tory MPs, who expected Britain to leave the EU on March  ndash then tomorrow ndash but now face the prospect of voters taking part in Mayrsquos European parliamentary elections and a possible delayed stay until the end of the year.Iain Duncan Smith, the former party leader, said Mrs May must be forced to goshe ed with a long extension from talks, as participating in European elections would be ldquoan utter disaster for the Tories.But in a development that is likely to infuriate Brexiter Tories, Downing Street has indicated her departure will depend on her EU withdrawal agreement being approved by MPs.Sir Bill Cash, the leading Tory Brexiter, tweeted a letter he had sent to Donald Tusk, the European Council President, claiming ldquoany decision by the Prime Minister to accept a long extension to Article  is likely to be challenged in the UK courts.:Brexit extension: What happens next  Will Theresa May quit  Heres everything you need to knowIn Brussels, Mrs May spent an hour making the case for a short extension to June , taking questions from fellow leaders and describing how she believed there was a chance her Governmentrsquos talks with the Labour opposition could produce a compromise solution that could get a Commons majority.EU sources described her performance as ldquosolid and helpful, much better than her previous presentation, which was regarded as cold, technical and unforthcoming. One insider said the PM claimed the talks with Labour were ldquogoing well, which, it was suggested, was not widely believed.As the meeting began there wasa moment of levity as German Chancellor Angela Merkel showed the PM a side-by-side image on her tablet computer of them wearing jackets of the same colour as they took questions in their respective Parliaments earlier inthe day.After Mrs May left following her presentation, the EU leaders discussed Brexit over dinner. It is thought none argued against a Brexit extension, just over how long it should be.Mrs Merkel emphasised the benefits of a longer delay to give Britain time to sort itself out ndash the ldquoflextension option outlined earlier in the week by Mr Tusk.Most EU leaders backed the idea. It is thought  supported a longer delay, but all , as well as the UK, had to agree on the final offer.Francersquos Emmanuel Macron preferred a shorter extension, warning the EU ran the risk of an obstructive UK still being in the bloc and that jeopardising the running of the EU was ldquonot preferable to a no-deal.Sophie Inrsquot Veld, deputy to Guy Verhofstadt, the EU Parliamentrsquos Brexit negotiator, said EU leaders were concerned about extending Brexit amid threats the UK could cause disruption were it to stay in the bloc after its elections.She told BBC Newsnight the EU could ask the UK to pledge not to cause problems but said there was a ldquobig question-mark over how reliable such a vow would beas it would have no legal backing.A further delay to Brexit piles more pressure on the PMrsquos future at home.Three weeks ago Mrs May appeared adamant she would not countenance serving any longer in No Britainrsquos membership of the EU were extended beyond June .She told MPs: ldquoAs Prime Minister, I am not prepared to delay Brexit any further than June .But ahead of the Brussels summit when pressed on this, she appeared to step back, saying the important issue was securing the flexibility to leave the EU early and avoid having to take part in the May Euro elections.Tory sources stressed the PM stood by her commitment to the backbench  Committee that she would hand over to a successor for the second phase of negotiations after ratication. Last night, the committee met in the Commons but did not discuss the PMrsquos future.In a swipe at the Brexit rebels who blocked her Withdrawal Agreement from passing through Parliament in time to leave on March , Mrs May said: ldquoI know many people are frustrated the summit is taking place at all because the UK should have left the EU by now.I greatly regret Parliament hasnrsquot been able to pass a deal that would have enabled us to leave in a smooth and orderly way.ldquoBut I and the Government continue to work to find a way forward. We have been talking with the Opposition. Therersquos been serious and constructive talks and they will continue tomorrow.Justice Secretary David Gauke made clear he believed the PM could stay on as Tory leader for another year. ldquoI donrsquot think we should be rushing to change our leader when there is a big task to be done, he said.On Tuesday, the scale of opposition within Tory parliamentary ranks to an extension was laid bare when nearly Tory MPs voted against the PMrsquos decision to ask for a three-month extension to the Article  process.Another  abstained, including four Cabinet ministers Andrea Leadsom, Liam Fox, Chris Grayling and Geoffrey Cox, which meant a majority of Tory MPs defied the leadership.During PMQs yesterday, Conservative MPs questioned the wisdom of any extension. Warwickshire Tory Craig Tracey told Mrs May the best way to respect the partyrsquos manesto commitments was "to go under WTO rules".Today, inter-party talks on Brexit are due to resume.Jeremy Corbynrsquos spokesman said the Government had found it ldquopretty dficult to move off their red lines.ldquoThere is still serious engagementand exploration of new and dferent elements and[Tuesdayrsquos] talks expanded the frame to include new areas.In a separate development, Nicola Sturgeon took to social media to underline what might be possible were Scotland an independent nation.Shetweeted: ldquoTonight,  of the  EU member states that will decide the UKrsquos future have populations smaller than or similar in size to Scotlandrsquos.ldquoIf we become independent we get to sit at that table - enjoying the same solidarity shown to Ireland - instead of being sidelined by Westminster.

title: giant-shetland-oil-field-start-up-delayed

title: eu-uk-must-take-part-in-european-election-or-leave-in-june
story: A document of the conclusions from the European Council after their special meeting to discuss Article  said: "The European Council underlines that the extension cannot be allowed to undermine the regular ing of the Union and its institutions.Read more: Theresa May granted Brexit extension"If the UK is still a Member of the EU on - May  andit has not ratied the Withdrawal Agreement by  May , it must hold the elections to the European Parliament in accordance with Union law."If the United Kingdom fails to live up to this obligation, the withdrawal will take place on  June ."Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar underlined the ultimatumin a tweet following the decision.And wersquore done.Flextension to Oct stWersquoll take stock of situation at our regular summit in JuneUK to take part in @Europarl_EN election or must leave on June st without a deal.Good night !Announcing the new flexible extension, President of the European Council Donald Tusk said: "Tonight the European Council decided to grant the United Kingdom a flexible extension of the Article  period until October ."This means an additional six months for the UK. During this time, the course of action will be entirely in the UKs hands."It can still raty the withdrawal agreement, in which case the extension will be terminated.Read more: SNP demand second EU referendum"It can also reconsider the whole Brexit strategy. That might lead to changes in the political declaration, but not in the withdrawal agreement."Until the end of this period, the UK will also have the possibility to revoke Article  and cancel Brexit altogether."Mr Tusk went on: "The UK will continue its sincere cooperation as a full member state, with all its rights, and as a close friend and trusted ally in the future."Let me finish with a message to our British friends: This extension is as flexible as I expected, and a little bit shorter than I expected, but its still enough to find the best possible solution. Please do not waste this time."A review of progress on Brexit set for June will involve the EU "taking stock" and is "not another clf edge", European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said.

story: A report from the Accounts Commission disclosed that Renfrewshire Council made more than  salary over-payments between April  and February .These amounted to about pound,, the report said, with six over-payments exceeding pound, and one person receiving pound, more than they should have.The Accounts Commission also found ldquoan eighth of former employees were still paid after leaving the council, usually due to a delay in a department notying payroll services staff that someone had left.Read more: Cuts leaving councils ripe for fraudThe council has recovered % of the money overpaid to current staff and % of that overpaid to former employees, but the commission noted it has written off pound, of the cash.A Renfrewshire Council spokesman said: ldquoThe risk of overpayments exists for all organisations and we have robust recovery processes in place for all debts owed, including salary overpayments, and we always take all appropriate action to recover all overpayments.Details of the financial error were revealed in a new report from the local government spending watchdog, which warned systems aimed at preventing money being lost through mistakes and fraud may be becoming ldquostrained.It said: ldquoThere are signs from councilsrsquo internal auditors and the work of councilsrsquo external auditors that standards of internal controls may be strained.Read more: Fewer than  in  council vehicles are eco-friendlyldquoSome recurring weaknesses are becoming apparent among councils and the consequences could be serious, including the loss of signicant amounts of public money, impacts on services and reputational damage.Graham Sharp, chair of the Accounts Commission, said: ldquoRobust management and scrutiny of the finances at Scotlandrsquos councils is more important now than ever before.ldquoCouncils face complex and challenging financial pressures, and rising demand for services. title: nicola-sturgeons-expresses-relief-after-brexit-extension-agreed
story: Taking to social media, the SNP leadersaid it was "a relief" that the UK would not be "crashing out" of the EU without a deal on Friday.:Theresa May is given six-month extension from EU on BrexitShe wrote: "It is a relief that - thanks to the patience of the EU - we will not be crashing out tomorrow. Please do not waste this time."A review of progress on Brexit set for June will involve the EU "taking stock" and is "not another clf edge", European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said.A document of the conclusions from the European Council after their special meeting to discuss Article  said: "The European Council underlines that the extension cannot be allowed to undermine the regular ing of the Union and its institutions."If the UK is still a Member of the EU on - May  andit has not ratied the Withdrawal Agreement by  May , it must hold the elections to the European Parliament in accordance with Union law."If the United Kingdom fails to live up to this obligation, the withdrawal will take place on  June ."It is a relief that - thanks to the patience of the EU - we will not be crashing out tomorrow. But the UK must not waste this time - allowing people to decidethey still want to leave is now imperative. And Scotlandrsquos interests must be protected.Mr Juncker added: "We will have a Brexit with a deal. I would have preferred a deal without Brexit."AskedBrexit could be extended again, Mr Tusk said: "Our intention is to finalise the whole process in October.:Brexit: How politicians reacted to -month extension"The political intention was clear among the member states that our wish and our hope is that the UK will be ready with the final solution." days is plenty of time for lots of things - including a referendum  revocation. But the biggest message from tonight should be drawn from the utter powerlessness of a #Brexiting UK . Time for Scotland to be in the room shaping decisions, not outside the door.Last night, Theresa May expressed her frustration that Brexit had not been delivered.She said she hoped to leave the EU before the  OctoberMPs passed her deal saying:"I know that there is huge frustration from many people that I had to request this extension."The UK should have left the EU by now and I sincerely regret the fact that I have not yet been able to persuade parliament to approve a deal."She added: "I do not pretend the next few weeks will be easy, or there is a simple way to break the deadlock in parliament. But we have a duty as politicians to find a way to fulfil the democratic decision of the referendum, deliver Brexit and move our country forward."Nothing is more pressing or more vital."

title: brian-souter-disappointed-by-alex-salmond-allegations

title: extreme-weather-cost-scottish-farmers-116m-last-year
story: The losses equated to around % of the total agricultural output of the previous year, experts found.:Five farming deaths in Scotland this yearThe livestock sector was hit hardest by the double impact of severe snow in March and higher feeding costs over the hot summer.Environmental charity WWF Scotland said farmers were ldquoincreasingly on the front-line of climate change as they work to cope with unpredictable seasons.The Beast from the East snowstorm in March last year brought the most signicant spell of severe winter weather since December , with snow depths up to cm or more across upland areas.It was followed by the joint hottest summer on record for the UK.The Economic Impact of Extreme Weather on Scottish Agriculture report was commissioned by WWF Scotland and compiled by economic consultancy Ecosulis.It concluded that the severe weather of   impacted on livestock numbers and yields of key crops.Sheep farmers suffered the biggest hit as the Beast from the East swept in during lambing season, with losses of pound million.This was followed by wheat , beef , and barley .The report said: ldquoThe overall losses to Scottish agriculture are estimated at pound million, equivalent to % of total output in .ldquoIn terms of animal deaths, the biggest impact was also on the sheep sector, the beef sector also suffered substantial losses, but the largest impact on beef was on the cost of forage and increased feeding due to the longer housing period.ldquoDue to a longer production cycle the impact on the beef sector is likely to be felt for some time.:New entrants to farming bring new ideasThe reportrsquos authors added that the poor weather may have contributed to the decision of some dairy farmers to cease production, and said some farmers may have experienced losses as a result of uncollected milk.ldquoLosses to inidual dairy farmers, however, were as high as pound,, the publication noted.Cereal yields were also affected signicantly and overall losses to the cereal sector were pound million ndash equivalent to % of the sectorrsquos output in , the report noted.Meanwhile, farmers also experienced building damage due to heavy snow and strong winds bringing down roofs and burst pipes.Insurers also reported an increase in fires during June and July due to the exceptionally hot, dry summer.Dr Sheila George, food policy manager at WWF Scotland, said: ldquoFarmers are increasingly on the front-line of climate change, struggling with ever more unpredictable seasons and extreme weather.ldquoThis report gives a snapshot of the huge financial toll, but behind these stats there is also a personal cost for farmers across the country.ldquoLast yearrsquos extremes will soon be the norm rather than the exception and that will have huge implications for farmers and the environment.Thatrsquos why itrsquos so important the Scottish Government takes action now to support our agriculture sector to adapt to the challenges ahead.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoOur farmers, crofters and land managers are on the front line when it comes to dealing with unpredictable seasons and extreme weather.ldquoThat is why we continue to engage with the industry to ensure that appropriate support is provided during challenging times.ldquoThis has included offering support to our farming communities through the early payment of loans, securing derogations from European rules, and our continued support of the work of the Agricultural Weather Advisory Panel and Farm Advisory Service.ldquoWe encourage all farmers, crofters and land managers to consider how they can look to improve the resilience of their business both financially and environmentally moving forward.

For many in the newsroom - and the audience across the country - she just is Reporting Scotland. Irsquoll miss her, the team in the newsroom will miss her, Scotland will miss her.":BBC Scotland spends pound, on taxis in last yearBBC Scotland Director Donalda MacKinnon said: "Ive had the pleasure of working with Jackie for many years now and its been very reassuring for me and for many of us that shes been at the helm of the countrys most watched news programme." Shes a brilliant journalist and multi-talented broadcaster who will, I hope, continue to work with us here at BBC Scotland."She was an inspiration to many female colleagues particularly during her earlier years when newsrooms were largely dominated by men. I am certain that she will continue to inspire and influence in all she does next.

hours of this morning to extend the Article  withdrawal process to October  in order to avoid a no-deal exit on Friday.Theresa May had requested a shorter delay until the end of June, but her counterparts at an emergency summit in Brussels did not believe she could secure a Brexit deal by then.However the UK will be allowed to cut short the extensionMrs May strikes a deal with Labour or MPs reached consensus on another option, such as a customs union.In response, Ms Sturgeon said it was a ldquorelief that the UK would not be ldquocrashing out thanks to the patience of the EU.On Twitter, she said the extra time should be used to put Brexit to a Peoplersquos Vote.She said: ldquoThe UK must not waste this time - allowing people to decidethey still want to leave is now imperative. And Scotlandrsquos interests must be protected.:Nicola Sturgeon expresses relief after Brexit extension agreedIn practice, it would be extremely dficult to hold a second EU referendum by the end of October - and onlythe UK Government started work on it immediately.Some senior SNP figures, including Mr MacNeil, have frequentlycriticised Ms Sturgeonrsquos emphasis on a Peoplersquos Vote, calling it a distraction from independence.:SNP MP tells Nicola Sturgeon people have waited long enough for IndyrefMs Sturgeon is now facing calls from within the SNP hierarchy to prioritise Indyref.Mr McEleny, who has twice run for the SNP deputy leadership and represents ordinary members on the National Executive, said: ldquoBrexit has crystallised for many that as part of the UK the voice and the opinion of Scotland simply does not matter.ldquoAs part of the UK we are now being dragged out of the EU regardless of what people in Scotland want.ldquoWith an extension to the end of October, we now have the clarity that people required. People in Scotland should be given the opportunity to voice their preference on the future they want for Scotland.ldquoBefore the UK leaves the EU, it is now time to press with everything we have to give people the opportunity to decidethey want Scotlandrsquos future relationship with the EU decided for them, orthey want to take that decision into their own hands, by deciding that Scotland should become an independent country.ldquoAn independence referendum in September of this year would give us that opportunity.The issue is likely to come up at the SNP conference at the end of this month.Ms Sturgeon is already facing a grassroots backlash over the leaderships plan to keep using the pound after independence.Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said: ldquoThe SNP is deeply split over its plans to scrap the pound, and now there are fresh splits emerging over Nicola Sturgeonrsquos indyref strategy.ldquoIt is deeply irresponsible and reckless to advocate a isive second independence referendum as early as this autumn.ldquoWith the Brexit deadline extended and further uncertainty for our economy, the very last thing we need is even more constitutional uncertainty.ldquoItrsquos time for Nicola Sturgeon to listen to the majority of people in Scotland and drop the threat of an unwanted second independence referendum.Scottish Conservative chief whip Maurice Golden said: "These remarks expose the motivation of the SNPrsquos involvement in the Brexit process.ldquoNationalists arenrsquot interested in a successful departure from the EU.ldquoInstead, they want to stoke ision and use any and every opportunity to demand another independence vote.ldquoThat will always be the SNPrsquos one and only priority, and proves why the party is utterly unfit for government.Asked about using the delay to push for a second independence referendum, Ms Sturgeon told Bauer Scotland: ldquoIrsquoll set out my thinking on that after the Easter recess [at Holyrood].ldquoBut I understand the impatience of people who, like me, believe absolutely that the best future for Scotland is to be independent.ldquoLast night, those countries that were deciding the UKrsquos future with the UK out of the room included a dozen countries that have populations smaller than or similar in size to Scotland, yet itrsquos Scotland thatrsquos completely sidelined by Westminster in this whole process.ldquoSo, ironically, Brexit, which was all about taking back control for Westminster, has actually highlighted how much power and influence Small countries have within the European Union.ldquoSo the case for independence is stronger than itrsquos ever been. But we need to do things at the right time and in the right way. Because wersquove got to convince a majority, not just of the SNP, but a majority of the people of Scotland that independence is the best future.An SNP spokesperson added: "Scotland has been ignored by the UK Government throughout this whole Brexit disaster.ldquoThe contrast between the contempt shown to Scotland by the Tories and the influence other countries our size have exerted as independent EU members couldnrsquot be clearer.

title: in-full-nicola-sturgeon-writes-to-theresa-may-following-article-50-extension
story: The First Minister said it is "essential now that this time is used constructively and not wasted".She alsocalled for ongoing talks over EU exit to include the devolved administrations, and for any deal agreed by the UK Parliament to be put to a second referendum.: Brexit live: Theresa May to make statement to Commons after Brexit delayHere is the full text of the letter:"Dear Theresa"I am writing to you today following the agreement reached at the European Council last night to extend the Article  period to the end of October , with a review in June."It is welcome that the European Union has acted in this way to give the UK more time. However, it is essential now that this time is used constructively and not wasted."People in Scotland voted overwhelmingly to remain in the EU but have been ignored by the UK Government throughout the Brexit process. That must now change."Notwithstanding the clear remain result in Scotland, the Scottish Government has sought to engage meaningfully on the terms of the UKrsquos departure from the EU and has called consistently for genuine efforts to reach consensus across party lines and with the devolved administrations.However, it is still not clear that even at this late stage and following the repeated defeat of your proposals that you are willing to drop your red lines which have restricted what can be achieved in the future relationship."We now have the gt of more time from the EU, and that must be used constructively to re-set the UK Government approach. Your ongoing talks with the Leader of the Opposition should now broaden to include other parties, the devolved administrations, business and civic society, and open up the range of options on the table in an effort to reach a genuine consensus. If such talks are to stand any chance of success you must be prepared to recognise in particular that it is essential for Scotland, at the very least, to stay inside the Single Market and continue to benefit from freedom of movement."Further, and more fundamentally, the Scottish Government considers that any deal agreed by the UK Parliament should be put to another referendum, with the alternative proposition on the ballot paper being to remain in the EU. The extension to  October provides enough time to do this, and it is essential that no time is lost in making the necessary preparations."I urge you to convene an urgent cross-party and cross-administration discussion to agree how to use the time we have been given."I am copying this letter to the First Minister of Wales, Mark Drakeford."

title: orkneys-ring-of-brodgar-stones-circle-vandalised
story: Damage to the Ring of Brodgar includes graffiti which has been engraved into one of the stones at the Neolithic site near Stenness.It is believed to have been caused sometime between Friday afternoon and Sunday morning.Inspector David Hall said: ldquoThe stones at the Ring of Brodgar are priceless historical artefacts and the damage caused cannot simply be estimated in monetary terms.ldquoFor someone to damage them in this way is a particularly mindless act.:Ancient structure discovered on OrkneyldquoI would urge anyone who has visited the area over the last weekend to think back andthey believe they may have seen something suspicious, evenit didnrsquot seem of much note at the time, to let us know.ldquoWe would also urge the public to continue to be vigilant at this site and report anything which could be of interest to police immediately.The Ring of Brodgaroriginally consisted of  stones, with  surviving today.It is within the Heart of Neolithic OrkneyUnesco World Heritage Site.This also includes alarge chambered tomb called Maes Howe, the Stones of Stenness and a settlement ndash Skara Brae.: Were mysterious carved balls just ancient sculptors CV The ring was built around ,-,BC and covers an area of almost , square metres.It is the third largest stone circle in the British Isles ndash behind Avebury and Stanton Drew ndash and is the largest in Scotland.One of the stones has already been vandalised,carrying a Norse runic inscription, while at least one other has been struck by lightning.Celebrated visitors include Sir Walter Scott, who in  wrote of the Ring of Brodgar and Stones of Stenness that ldquoStonehenge excels these monuments, but I fancy they are otherwise unparalleled in Britain.Historic Environment Scotland notes suggestions that the sites and monuments in the surrounding areawere used for astrological observations from the Ring of Brodgar, but it is veryhard to find conclusive evidence.A Historic Environment Scotland spokeswoman said: ldquoWe were recently made aware of an incident of vandalism to the Ring of Brodgar.ldquoWe would ask the public to be aware that causing reckless or deliberate damage to a scheduled monument is a criminal offence, and ask that anyone witnessing such acts report them to Police Scotland.

title: mp-proposes-law-to-ensure-scottish-banknotes-are-accepted-uk-wide
story: The move comes after Judy Murray tweeted about her Scottish note being refused when she tried to buy doughnuts at a London bakery.: Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedThe tennis coach, and mother to tennis stars Andy and Jamie Murray, said she was told ldquowe only take British ones, when trying to pay with a Scottish banknote.When you go to pay pound for  donutsin London and your pound Bank of Scotland note is refused because ldquowe only take British ones. ## pic SCCzIfolDnmdash judy murrayApril , Scottish Liberal Democrat deputy leader Alistair Carmichael has lodged a Bill in the House of Commons to have Scottish banknotes accepted throughout the UK and to oblige businesses to accept them as payment.Scottish banknotes are legal currency in the UK but not legal tender.No banknotes are classed as legal tender in Scotland and the Royal Mint explains the phrase is a narrow technical term referring to the settlement of debts, and in ordinary transactions both parties can agree to accept ldquoany form of payment.Mr Carmichaelrsquos Legal TenderBill would mean no distinction could be drawn between Scottish banknotes and others in the UK as forms of payment.He said: ldquoEvery Scot who travels south has a story about their money being turned down or looked at sceptically.ldquoThere is no reason to make a distinction between Scottish and other banknotes as acceptable payment.ldquoItrsquos beyond time we give legal force to the well-known phrase lsquothatrsquos legal tender, palrsquo.ldquoI hope that this Bill will encourage businesses across the UK to recognise and accept Scottish currency.:Judy Murrays Scottish banknotes refused in London bakersAn earlier attempt to legislate for Scottish banknotes to be accepted throughout the UK was made by current Scottish Secretary David Mundell.His Scottish BanknotesBill was put before the UK Parliament in  but was not made law.

title: in-full-theresa-mays-statement-to-mps-after-eu-summit
story: She addressed the Commons on Thursday afternoon, and said it was the national duty of MPs to agree a Brexit deal.Read more:Theresa May is given six-month extension from EU on BrexitShe said that an agreement cant be reach, options will be put in front of the House to determine a way forward.She began her statement with a nod to the politan Police, who arrested Wiki Leaks founder Julian Assange this morning.Read more:WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange arrested at the Ecuadorian embassyHere is the statement in full:"My priority is to deliver Brexit ndash and to do so in an orderly way that does not disrupt peoplersquos lives."So I continue to believe we need to leave the European Union with a deal as soon as possible."And of course, this House has voted repeatedly to avoid a No Deal."Yet despite the efforts of Members on all sides, we have not so far been able to vote for a deal."So ahead of the Council, I wrote to President Tusk to seek a short extension to the Article  period to th June.Read more:Theresa Mays letter to Donald Tusk requesting Article  extension"Critically, I also requested that any extension should be terminable - so that whenever this House agrees a deal and raties the Withdrawal Agreement, we can get on and leave."And I did this not merely to avoid a further delay beyond ratication of the Withdrawal Agreement - but specically to retain our ability to leave the EU without having to hold European Parliamentary elections on the rd May."Mr Speaker, the discussions at the Council were dficult and unsurprisingly many of our European partners share the deep frustration that I know so many of us feel in this House over the current impasse."There was a range of views about theof an extension with a large number of Member States preferring a longer extension to the end of this year or even into the next."In the end what was agreed by the UK and the EU was a compromise ndash an extension lasting until the end of October.Read more:UK must take part in European elections or leave in June, says EU"The Council also agreed that we would update on our progress at the next meeting in June."Critically ndash as I requested ndash the Council agreed that this extension can be terminated when the Withdrawal Agreement has been ratied."So, for example,we were to pass a deal by nd May, we would not have to take part in European elections. And when the EU has also ratied, we would be able to leave at pm on st May."In short, the date of our departure from the EU ndash and our participation in the European Parliamentary Elections - remains a decision for this House."As President Tusk said last night: ldquoDuring this time, the course of action will be entirely in the UKrsquos hands.Read more:Nicola Sturgeon expresses relief after Brexit extension agreed"In agreeing this extension, there was some discussion in the Council about whether stringent conditions should be imposed on the UK for its EU membership during this period."But I argued against this."I put the case that there is only a single tier of EU membership, with no conditionality attached beyond existing treaty obligations."The Council conclusions are clear that during the course of the extension the UK will continue to hold full membership rights."In turn, I assured my fellow leaders that the UK will continue to be bound by all our ongoing obligations as a Member State, including the duty of sincere co-operation."The United Kingdom plays a responsible and constructive role on the world stage ndash and we always will."That is the kind of country we are."The choices we face are stark and the timetable is clear."I believe we must now press on at pace with our efforts to reach a consensus on a deal that is in the national interest.Read more:The best Twitter jokes about new Halloween Brexit date"I welcome the discussions that have taken place with the Opposition in recent days - and the further talks which are resuming today."This is not the normal way of British politics - and it is uncomfortable for many in both the Government and Opposition parties."Reaching an agreement will not be easy, because to be successful it will require both sides to make compromises."But however challenging it may be politically, I profoundly believe that in this unique situation where the House is deadlocked, it is incumbent on both front benches to seek to work together to deliver what the British people voted for. And I think that the British people expect their politicians to do just that when the national interest demands it."I hope that we can reach an agreement on a single unied approach that we can put to the House for approval."Butwe cannot do so soon, then we will seek to agree a small number of options for the future relationship that we will put to the House in a series of votes to determine which course to pursue."And as I have made clear before, the Government stands ready to abide by the decision of the House. But to make this process work, the Opposition would need to agree to this too."With the Housersquos consent, we could also bring forward the Withdrawal Agreement Bill ndash which is a necessary element of any deal, whichever course we take.Read more:What happens next  Will Theresa May quit  Heres everything you need to know"This Bill will take time to pass through both Houses, sowe want to get on with leaving, we need to start this process soon."And it could also provide a useful forum to resolve some of the outstanding issues in the future relationship."Crucially, Mr Speaker, any agreement on the future relationship may involve a number of additions and clarications to the Political Declaration."So I am pleased that at this Council, all  Member States responded to my update on the ongoing cross-party talks by agreeing that - ldquothe European Council is prepared to reconsider the Political Declaration on the future relationship in accordance with the positions and principles stated in its guidelines and statements."The Council also reiterated that the Withdrawal Agreement itself could not be reopened."Mr Speaker, I know the whole country is intensely frustrated that this process to leave the European Union has not still been completed."I never wanted to seek this extension ndash and I deeply regret that we have not yet been able to secure agreement in this House for a deal that would allow us to leave in a smooth and orderly way.Read more:SNP demand second EU referendum after Brexit delay"I know too that this whole debate is putting Members on all sides of the House under immense pressure and causing uncertainty across the country."And we need to resolve this."So let us use the opportunity of the Recess to reflect on the decisions that will have to be made swtly on ourafter Easter. And let us then resolve to find a way through this impasse."So that we can leave the European Union with a deal as soon as possible."So that we can avoid having to hold those European Parliamentary elections."And above all, so that we can fulfil the democratic decision of the Referendum, deliver Brexit and move our country forward."This is our national duty as elected members of this House ndash and nothing today is more pressing or more vital."And I commend this Statement to the House."

title: halloween-horror-how-europe-reacted-to-the-latest-brexit-delay
story: As news of the latest Brexit extension reverberated across the continent, there were some brutal words for the UK.France ndash whose president, Emmanuel Macron, pushed hardest against handing Theresa May a long delay ndash gave perhaps the most stinging assessment.The EUrsquos six month extension was splashed across the front page of Le Monde.In a blistering editorial, it said there is ldquoevery reason to be exasperated by the British, who have been unable to resolve the Brexit crisis and have ldquocome again to lay the bowl to beg for a grace period.Read more:SNP split over referendum priority in Brexit delayThe newspaper said Westminster had embarked on an ldquointerminable Monty Python sketch, with a cacophony of voices backing dferent positions ndash hard or soft Brexit, membership of a customs union, a second referendum.It added: ldquoThe danger is great that this British madness will reach a European continent that really does not need that.One correspondent said the UK Government was so chaotic and Mrs Mayrsquos authority so degraded that ldquoanything is possible.Does the Brexit horror never stop  asks German tabloid BildElsewhere, French newspaper Libeacuteration said Mrs May had obtained her extension at a price ndash ldquothe united front displayed by the European leaders has shattered.It pointed to the open disagreement between France and Germany over whether to give the UK a y extension.Mr Macron, the French president, was adamant a long extension ndash favoured by Germany ndash risked weakening Europe.Libeacuterationrsquos Brussels correspondent Jean Quatremer wrote: ldquoOne wonders whether the United Kingdom will ever end up leaving the Union.He said nothing guaranteed the October  extension would be the last, and the repeated delays ldquoshow that the United Kingdom has managed the feat of exporting its internal Byzantine battles [to] Brussels.He also raised fears shared by others across Europe: that the UK could use its continued membership of the EU to deliberately cause trouble in order to force a renegotiation of the Brexit deal.Germanyrsquos Die Welt said Brexit ldquois no longer a British affair, and had impacted on European unity.Die Zeit, meanwhile, said the new exit date ldquocould not be more symbolic: on  October, when the Halloween festival of horrors is being celebrated everywhere, Britain is set to leave the EU.It added: ldquoFor many, in Britain and on the continent, a truly scary moment.Read more:In full: Nicola Sturgeon writes to Theresa May following Article  extensionSpanish newspaper El Pais noted the ldquodficult balance of the new pact meant it risked neither piling pressure on Westminster to approve Mrs Mayrsquos deal, nor scaring Eurosceptics with the prospect of a long extension killing off Brexit.Barcelonarsquos La Vanguardia said both those who voted for Brexit and the remaining  EU members had reason to feel aggrieved.Elsewhere, a headline on the website of the German tabloid Bild read simply: ldquoDoes the Brexit horror never stop It said the new delay would be ldquojust enough to hold a second referendum or new electionsa cross-party majority could be found.A chaotic exit may have been avoided for now, but it added: ldquoThe Brexit scourge and uncertainty for business and iniduals continues.ldquoThe EU did not even rule out that the deadline could be extended a second time by the end of October.A piece in Italyrsquos La Stampa was also pessimistic. It said: ldquoWhatever the outcome of the last act of this tragedy, Brexit is destined to mark the future of Europe for at least a generation.Confidence between the UK and the continent, the article noted, has been broken in a lasting way.EU leaders had their say on the extension during Wednesday eveningrsquos Brexit summit.Afterwards, European Council presidentDonald Tusksaid the delay was a little shorter than expected but ldquostill enough to find the best possible solution, adding: "Please do not waste this time.Spainrsquos prime minister Pedro Saacutenchez did not mince his words when he took aim at the  Leave campaign.Read more:In full: Theresa Mays statement to MPs after EU summitHe said: ldquoThe most important lesson we need to learn from whatrsquos happening in the UK is that when decision-making processes, based on lies, are put in the hands of the people, societies ndash in this case British society ndash wind up down a blind alley.ldquoWe in the EU need to be conscious of the scale of the challenge British society is facing and we need to try to help it reach an agreement.ldquoDates may y, but the important thing is to give British politics the time it needs to find its way out of a situation that stems from a referendum held three years ago.Polish prime minister Mateusz Morawiecki said the delay ldquogives a chance to overcome the ratication crisis in [the] UK.He added: ldquoIt is now up to [the] UK to take this opportunity.Irish prime minister Leo Varadkar said: ldquoItrsquos three years since the referendum now and we really think itrsquos time for the United Kingdom to make a decision, so wersquore giving them a very long period of time now to make a decision.

title: jackie-bird-on-her-last-reporting-scotland-i-just-about-got-through-the-bulletin-i-kept-it-all-in
story: Ms Bird, who is leaving her post as presenter of Reporting Scotland after  years this week, said she deliberately left little time at the end of the Wednesday night bulletin so she could hold her emotions in check.The journalist, , said she is not leaving the BBC, and hopes to work on other current affairs projects for the station, as well as the new BBC Scotland news channel.Read more:Jackie Bird leaves BBC Reporting Scotland after  yearsShe said: "I only told my immediate boss and the boss above [the head of news], I was remarkable that it didnt leak, but it was kept a secret."I didnt want to lose control of my emotions,the staff had been waiting to see me off, I didnt want to start crying."She added: "I just about got through the bulletin, I kept it all in."The news should not be about the presenter. But it was very emotional. I played it so that there wasnt too much time at the end to say goodbye for the last time."I didnt want to make the news for the wrong reasons."The broadcaster said that she felt  years was the right landmark to call an end to her time reporting the news for Reporting Scotland.Read more:Scottish Twitter reacts as Jackie Bird leaves BBC Reporting ScotlandShe now has "irons in the fire", working on current affairs projects for the corporation on radio and TV, and has not ruled out presenting set piece news events in the future.Asked how she would feel when big news stories break in the future, she said: "I will be beside myself. But its the end of my time at Reporting Scotland, not the BBC. I will be therecalled upon, and I am definitely not retiring."Thirty years is a long time to do the same job. Reporting Scotland is getting some of its highest ratings, and I love the new channel, I hope to be working on the new channel. Theres been no fall outs, theres no other story - its a very big, scary decision for me, to leave now."

title: theresa-may-faces-down-tory-calls-to-resign-over-abject-surrender-to-brussels-on-brexit
story: Just hours after another bruising European Council when EU leaders agreed to a six-month extension to Hallowersquoen, a weary-looking Prime Minister took to the Commons dispatch box to make clear she was determined to see Brexit through despite the continuing dficulties.However, Mrs May was met by a wave of Conservative fury, expressed most keenly by veteran Eurosceptic Sir Bill Cash, who askedshe appreciated the ldquoanger that her abject surrender last night has generated across the country Accusing the PM of breaking the promise she made  times not to delay Brexit, the Staffordshire MP asked: ldquoDoes she also accept that this Withdrawal Agreement undermines our democracy, the constitutional status of Northern Ireland, our right to govern ourselves, our control over our laws, and our national interest  Will she resign Mrs May replied: ldquoYou know the answer to that, stressing how she had voted for Britain to leave the EU on March  and May  but, sadly, not enough colleagues had done the same, so an extension was required to enable MPs to agree on a deal.Leading Tory Brexiteer Mark Francois accused the PM of "sheer obstinacy" by agreeing to another extension despite her several failures to get her Withdrawal Agreement passed while his fellow Conservative Eurosceptic Peter Bone asked Mrs May how she would ldquohonour her commitment from last month when she suggested she would not stay in No Britain remained in the EU beyond June .In response, the PM declared: ldquoThis House and I can honour that commitment by voting for a deal that enables us to leave before June .During Commons exchanges, she received some encouragement when her Tory colleague Sarah Newton urged Mrs May to ldquoignore the bullies on our backbenches and stick to your guns and deliver that Brexithellipin our manesto.While Tory rules make clear the party leader cannot be challenged until December following her confidence motion victory before Christmas, David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary, insisted in the wake of the EU summit the ldquopressure on her to go will increase dramatically.The Yorkshire MP said it was dficult to see how his colleague could remain as PM by the time of the autumn Conservative conference given the forthcoming European elections would be a ldquoplebiscite on Brexit.Mr Davis noted: ldquoI suspect you will see a very successful rise of a sort of Brexit movement, the Nigel Farage thing. That will behellipvery dficult for her. So, the pressure on her will grow."But Andrew Bowie, the West Aberdeenshire and Kincardine Conservative, rallied to Mrs Mayrsquos defence, telling The Herald: ldquoThe PM is not going anywhere until this process is done. She is determined to see it through and is putting the national interest first.The backbencher, who is the PMrsquos Parliamentary Private Secretary, added: ldquoItrsquos not in the national interest to open up a isive, self-serving leadership election. The country does not want it and does not need it. The PM wants the UK to leave in good order and to respect the wishes of the people who voted in the referendum.During her Commons statement, Mrs May appealed to MPs to come together to pass a Brexit deal."We need to resolve this so we can leave the EU with a deal as soon as possible. This is our national duty as elected members of this House and nothing today is more pressing or more vital."Jeremy Corbyn claimed a second delay in leaving the EU within a fortnight represented ldquonot only a diplomatic failure but it is another milestone in the Governments mishandling of the entire Brexit process".Ian Blackford for the SNP declared: ldquoScotland will not support a Brexit deal cooked up by the Brexit-supporting Labour and Tory Parties.He pushed Mrs May to reveala second referendum had been offered during the Con-Lab talks. She replied it had not but noted how MPs could press their case for one when legislation to implement Brexit came forward.Commenting on the Con-Lab talks, the PM acknowledged reaching agreement would ldquonot be easy" as it would require compromise on both sides but she insisted it was in the "national interest" to try."This is not the normal way of British politics and it is uncomfortable for many in both the Government and opposition parties," she acknowledged."But however challenging it may be politically, I profoundly believe in this unique situation where the House is deadlocked, it is incumbent on both front benches to seek to work together to deliver what the British people voted for.The Labour leader said his party would continue to engage "constructively" in the negotiations, which were "serious, detailed and ongoing". But he warned ministers would have to compromisethey were to succeed.Contact between party officials engaged in the Con-Lab talks continued on Thursday and were followed by a ldquoshort meeting between the PM and Mr Corbyn. Frontbenchers from both sides are due to resume talks on Friday.However, a No  spokesman noted that while the talks had been constructive, they would not continue "for the sake of it".Government sources confirmed the next effective deadline to get a Commons deal was May , the day before voting begins in the European elections. While a parliamentary order has been laid for Britain to take part in the poll and parties are preparing to fight the elections,MPs backed a deal before polling day, then the plug would be pulled on them immediately.Following the granting of a new six-month extension, the First Minister wrote to Mrs May, saying it was a welcome development but the ldquogt of more time had to be used wisely to ldquoreset the UK Governmentrsquos approach.This should involve the convening of an ldquourgent cross-party and cross-administration discussion to agree how to use the time we have been given.Ms Sturgeon told the PM: ldquoYour ongoing talks with the Leader of the Opposition should now broaden to include other parties, the devolved administrations, business and civic society, and open up the range of options on the table to reach a genuine consensus.The FM arguedsuch talks were to stand any chance of success the UK Government had to recognise it was ldquoessential for Scotland, at the very least, to stay inside the single market and continue to benefit from freedom of movement.She added any agreed deal must be put to another referendum with Remain on the ballot paper. ldquoThe extension to October  provides enough time to do this and it is essential no time is lost in making the necessary preparations.But a UK Government spokeswoman replied: ldquoThere are already regular discussions at all levels between the UK and Scottish Government ahead of the UKrsquos exit from the EU to discuss the next steps in delivering Brexit in a smooth and orderly way.On Thursday, David Lidington, Mrs Mayrsquos de facto deputy, spoke to Michael Russell, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Constitutional Relations Secretary, to update him on the emergency European Council.On Friday, Nigel Faragersquos new Brexit Party is due to launch in Coventry.

title: analysis-theresa-may-is-determined-to-defy-tory-critics-and-see-brexit-to-the-end-if-she-can
story: Having revved up the engines on the runway twice now, the take-off has been dramatically stopped once again as the passengers couldnrsquot agree on the destination.It all means that three years after that fateful day in June , the UK will still be on the EU tarmac.The only thing certain about the Brexit process is, of course, the uncertainty.As Westminster lives day by day it is not a surprise that what was a firm declaration by Theresa May only just a week ago has suddenly vanished into thin air.Tory Brexiteer Peter Bone helpfully reminded the Prime Minister of her apparent promise that she would not countenance staying on in Downing StBritain were still in the EU by June . Which, of course, is a distinct possibility.How, asked the Northamptonshire MP, would Mrs May honour her commitment  ldquoI think you know the answer to that, snapped the PM, pointing out howMPs like Mr Bone voted for her deal, then Britain could indeed be out by June . But, of course, he wonrsquot.The Brexiteer knives are out for the PM but those close to her say she is determined to see Brexit through to a conclusionshe can.Tory rules state that a leader cannot be challenged for a year following a successful confidence vote. So, however hard the likes of Mark Francois and Andrew Bridgen try to oust their leader, it looks a forlorn hope. Mrs May has become inured to humiliation and is digging in her heels.Plus, as one Cabinet minister noted,she were to go, the parliamentary numbers would not alter. The idea that a new PM would somehow miraculously change the mood of Parliament and swing votes in their favour is another Brexit delusion.In practical terms, the PM has until May  to try to seal a deal to avoid British voters choosing a new raft of MEPs in the European parliamentary elections. Given the shortness of time, parties are already preparing candidates and campaigns. AskedMrs May would take part vigorously, a No  aide replied forcefully: ldquoWe want to avoid the elections, full stop.It would, of course, be another humiliation given the PM time and again has insisted she does not want to see the country going to the polls three years after it said it wanted to leave the EU.So can Theresa do it  Can she schmooze Jeremy Corbyn to get a compromise deal  There is a lot of talk about customs union customs arrangement and how the parties are in many ways on the same page.The PM was at it again on Thursday.ldquoThere is actually more agreement in relation to a customs union than is often given credit for when dferent language is used, she noted.ldquoWe are looking at the customs arrangement that would be in place in that future relationship. We have already indicated, as is in fact reflected in the Political Declaration, that we want to retain the benefits of a customs union no tarfs, no quotas and no rules of origin checks, Mrs May added.Yet, of course, whether or not the Labour leader will get into bed, politically, with his Tory counterpart is another question. Everyone talks about what is ldquoin the national interest. But the bottom line is Mr Corbyn believes having a Labour Government is in the national interest while Mrs May believes having a Tory one is in the national interest.Whether the inter-party talks succeed will ultimately come down to a political judgement which probably means they will not.Andthat results in MPs having another round of indicative votes, then this too is fraught with danger. One minister made clear for this to work there would have to be an ldquoabsolute majority of MPs backing one option not one that just has the most votes. And as we have seen no option has thus managed to rally most MPs behind it.And all the while Nicola Sturgeon bides her time on the independence question. A lack of certainty there will probably mean that when the First Minister comes to make her big announcement, after Easter, it will be fudged.As the nation faces another few weeks, months or even years of Brexitry, the decision at the EU summit raised at least one moment of joy.MPs were told Westminsterrsquos Easter recess, already curtailed and facing another week of parliamentary business, was being resurrected. Cheers erupted in the Commons chamber. It also has to be said members of HM Press were also leaping inside at the prospect of a few daysrsquo abstinence from Brexit.But then the madness will resume the engines will be revved up again. Only  days to Brexit. Possibly.

title: nicola-sturgeon-to-outline-indyref-plans-within-days
story: The First Minister, who has repeatedly delayed an update because of Brexit uncertainty, said she would update Holyrood after MSPs ed from the Easter recess on April .The announcement came amid a high-level rt in the SNP over how to use the six-month extension to Brexit agreed by EU leaders in the small hours of Wednesday morning.Ms Sturgeon said the new October  deadline should be used for a Peoplersquos Vote on remaining in Europe.However, one of her MPs and a member of the SNPrsquos ruling body said the priority should be a second independence referendum instead.Brexit has delayed any announcement onIndyref plansWestern Isles MP Angus Brendan MacNeil said the SNP should not be ldquokicking the Indyref can down the road and suggested a referendum could be held as soon as August.:SNP split over referendum priority in Brexit delayHe told The Herald: ldquoTheresa May might be kicking the can down the road but the Scottish Independence campaign shouldnrsquot be kicking the can down the road anymore.ldquoA campaign should be underway, plans to hold a referendum should be happening, and once a campaign is underway, we then decide on a date.Chris McEleny, the leader of the SNP on Inverclyde Council, and who represents party members on the its ruling National Executive Committee, said Scots should vote on independence in September.Mr McEleny, whose view is shared by many in the Yes movement, urged the SNP to put the drive for an independence referendum ldquofront and centre this summer.Asked about the urgent calls for Indyref, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoIrsquoll set out my thinking on that after the Easter recess. I understand the impatience of people who, like me, believe absolutely that the best future for Scotland is to be independent. The case for independence is stronger than itrsquos ever been.ldquoBut we need to do things at the right time and in the right way. Because wersquove got to convince a majority, not just of the SNP, but a majority of the people of Scotland that independence is the best future.:Alex Salmond takes swipe at SNP leadership over Indyref#Although she did not say exactly when after recess she should would update MSPs, the FM has pencilled in the week after next as it is her last opportunity to say something in parliament before the SNP spring conference.When, in March , Ms Sturgeon first announced a second referendum to offer voters an alternative to Brexit, it was in the week before the SNPrsquos spring conference.Theresa May has opposed any plans for a new voteAnnouncing a referendum at the conference itself would have looked ashe was driven by party concerns, undermining her message that she was acting in the national interest.Shortly after Ms Sturgeon called the referendum, Theresa May held a snap election in which the SNP lost a third of its MPs, forcing the First Minister to ldquoreset her plans.She promised a ldquoprecise timescale by autumn , when there was supposed to be clarity about Brexit, but it has been delayed by continued uncertainty.:Nicola Sturgeon expresses relief after Brexit extension agreed#With the UK facing a Tory leadership contest and a general election in the next few months, there is little prospect of Brexit clarity anytime soon.The Prime Minister is also certain to refuse Holyrood the power to hold a referendum.However Ms Sturgeon could use a refusal as a campaign tool at the  Holyrood election, citing as more evidence of Westminster ignoring Scotlandrsquos wishes.

title: a96 project to consider impact of new awpr
story: Two north east politicians have highlighted the need for the A dualling process to take into account the impact of the Aberdeen Western Peripheral Route.Current infrastructure plans for dualling the A past Inverurie to Huntly are in place, and a selection of route options are being analysed.During During Portfolio Questions at Holyrood on Thursday, April , Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin requested information on how the impact of the AWPR and the projected impact of dualling the railway line between Inverurie and Dyce, as well as the building of a new station at Kintore, is being analysed and taken into account as part of this process.Commenting, Gillian Martin MSP said: “The feedback on the AWPR to date has been extremely promising and I’m glad to hear that its impact, as well as that of other infrastructure projects in the area, will be taken into account as part of the design for the A dualling programme.“The dualling of the A is one of the next phases in transforming our infrastructure and it’s great to see increasing SNP investment in the North-East.“This is a long-awaited project which promises huge potential for the region and I look forward to its continuing development.”Meanwhile north east MSP Lewis Macdonald called on ministers to reconsider the shortlisted route options for dualling the A at Inverurie, to take into account up-to-date traffic data.Following a period of settling down of traffic behaviour, a traffic data collection exercise will be undertaken by Transport Scotland and a comparison made between the forecast and actual performance of the project.The Online Inverurie or OLI option for dualling the existing A on the edge of the town was ruled out by Transport Scotland last year.Lewis Macdonald, speaking after quizzing Transport Secretary Michael Matheson at Holyrood, said: “Taking the Online Inverurie option off the table at this early stage is not only premature, but it is based on data which is seriously out of date.“I met Michael Matheson last month, to argue that Online Inverurie should be on the shortlist of possible ways of upgrading the A. I told him how strongly many local people felt about this, because of the impact of building a whole new road north and east of the town.“He revealed that Transport Scotland has no intention of looking again at the A options, despite the fact that they have made their case on the basis of completely out-of-date information.“Road users from Inverurie and further west know full well that the AWPR has had a major impact on the A at Inverurie, which only strengthens the case for upgrading that specic stretch of existing road.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Connie Sorrie with the award and the Greengrocer family team"  National award for family firm viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“Ministers must listen to local people on this issue, and base any decisions on up-to-date traffic data. The AWPR has had a signicant impact on traffic flows in the area, and it would be a mistake to make multi-million pound decisions about trunk roads in the North East without collecting new data.“I urge Michael Matheson to address these concerns and ensure that the option of dualling the A along its current route at Inverurie is put back on the table.”

title: haddo house opens its doors for tours
